1.verse: From Adam to Abraham - Adam was the father of Seth [“was the father of” is added in verses 1–4; the Hebrew simply lists names; “father” can also mean “ancestor”]. Seth was the father of Enosh. Enosh was the father of Kenan.

2.verse: Kenan was the father of Mahalalel. Mahalalel was the father of Jared. Jared was the father of Enoch.

3.verse: Enoch was the father of Methuselah. Methuselah was the father of Lamech, and Lamech was the father of Noah.

4.verse: The sons of Noah were Shem, Ham, and Japheth.

5.verse: Japheth’s sons were Gomer, Magog, Madai, Javan, Tubal, Meshech, and Tiras.

6.verse: Gomer’s sons were Ashkenaz, ·Riphath [or Diphath; Gen. 10:3], and Togarmah.

7.verse: Javan’s sons were Elishah, Tarshish, Kittim [his descendants were the people of Cyprus], and ·Rodanim [or Dodanim; Gen. 10:4].

8.verse: Ham’s sons were Cush, Mizraim [another name for Egypt], Put, and Canaan.

9.verse: Cush’s sons were Seba, Havilah, Sabta, Raamah, and Sabteca. Raamah’s sons were Sheba and Dedan.

10.verse: Cush was the father of Nimrod, who ·grew up [was the first] to become a mighty warrior on the earth [Gen. 10:8–12].

11.verse: Mizraim was the father of the Ludites, Anamites, Lehabites, and Naphtuhites,

12.verse: Pathrusites, Casluhites, and Caphtorites. (The Philistines came from the Casluhites.)

13.verse: Canaan’s first child was Sidon. He was also the father of the Hittites,

14.verse: Jebusites, Amorites, Girgashites,

15.verse: Hivites, Arkites, Sinites,

16.verse: Arvadites, Zemarites, and Hamathites.

17.verse: Shem’s sons were Elam, Asshur, Arphaxad, Lud, and Aram. Aram’s sons were Uz, Hul, Gether, and ·Meshech [or Mash; Gen. 10:23].

18.verse: ·Arpachshad [or Arphaxad] was the father of Shelah, who was the father of Eber.

19.verse: Eber had two sons. One son was named Peleg [“divided”], because the people on the earth were divided [into different language groups or districts] during his ·life [days]. Peleg’s brother was named Joktan.

20.verse: Joktan was the father of Almodad, Sheleph, Hazarmaveth, Jerah,

21.verse: Hadoram, Uzal, Diklah,

22.verse: ·Obal [or Ebal; Gen. 10:28], Abimael, Sheba,

23.verse: Ophir, Havilah, and Jobab. All these were Joktan’s sons.

24.verse: The ·family [clan] line included Shem, ·Arphaxad [or Arpachshad], Shelah,

25.verse: Eber, Peleg, Reu,

26.verse: Serug, Nahor, Terah,

27.verse: and Abram, who was called [later] Abraham [Gen. 17:5–6].

28.verse: Abraham’s Family - Abraham’s sons were Isaac and Ishmael.

29.verse: These ·were the sons [are the descendants/genealogies] of Isaac and Ishmael. Ishmael’s ·first son [firstborn] was Nebaioth. His other sons were Kedar, Adbeel, Mibsam,

31.verse: Jetur, Naphish, and Kedemah. These were Ishmael’s sons.

32.verse: Keturah, Abraham’s ·slave woman [concubine; a secondary wife], gave birth to Zimran, Jokshan, Medan, Midian, Ishbak, and Shuah. Jokshan’s sons were Sheba and Dedan.

33.verse: Midian’s sons were Ephah, Epher, Hanoch, Abida, and Eldaah. All these were descendants of Keturah [Gen. 25:1–4].

34.verse: Abraham was the father of Isaac, and Isaac’s sons were Esau and Israel.

35.verse: Esau’s sons were Eliphaz, Reuel, Jeush, Jalam, and Korah.

36.verse: Eliphaz’s sons were Teman, Omar, ·Zephi [or Zepho; Gen. 36:11], Gatam, Kenaz, Timna, and Amalek.

37.verse: Reuel’s sons were Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah.

38.verse: The Edomites from Seir - Seir’s sons were Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah, Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan.

39.verse: Lotan’s sons were Hori and Homam, and his sister was Timna.

40.verse: Shobal’s sons were ·Alian [or Alvan; Gen. 36:23], Manahath, Ebal, ·Shepho [or Shephi; Gen. 36:23], and Onam. Zibeon’s sons were Aiah and Anah.

41.verse: Anah’s son was Dishon. Dishon’s sons were ·Hemdan [or Hamran; Gen. 36:26], Eshban, Ithran, and Keran.

42.verse: Ezer’s sons were Bilhan, Zaavan, and ·Akan [or Jaakan; Gen. 36:27]. Dishan’s sons were Uz and Aran.

43.verse: The Kings of Edom - These kings ·ruled [reigned] in Edom before there were kings in Israel [Gen. 36:31–39]. Bela son of Beor was king of Edom, and his city was named Dinhabah.

44.verse: When Bela died, Jobab son of Zerah became king. He was from Bozrah.

45.verse: When Jobab died, Husham became king. He was from the land of the Temanites.

46.verse: When Husham died, Hadad son of Bedad became king, and his city was named Avith. Hadad defeated Midian in the ·country [land; plains; field] of Moab.

47.verse: When Hadad died, Samlah became king. He was from Masrekah.

48.verse: When Samlah died, Shaul became king. He was from Rehoboth ·by [on; near] the river [perhaps the Euphrates River].

49.verse: When Shaul died, Baal-Hanan son of Acbor became king.

50.verse: When Baal-Hanan died, Hadad became king, and his city was named ·Pau [Pai]. Hadad’s wife was named Mehetabel, and she was the daughter of Matred, who was the daughter of Me-Zahab.

51.verse: Then Hadad died. The ·leaders of the family groups [clan/tribal leaders; chiefs] of Edom were Timna, Alvah, Jetheth,

54.verse: Magdiel, and Iram. These were the ·leaders [clan/tribal leaders; chiefs] of Edom.

1.verse: Israel’s Family - The sons of Israel [another name for Jacob] were Reuben, Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Zebulun,

2.verse: Dan, Joseph, Benjamin, Naphtali, Gad, and Asher.

3.verse: Judah’s Family - Judah’s sons were Er, Onan, and Shelah. A Canaanite woman, ·the daughter of Shua [or Bath-shua], was their mother. Judah’s ·first son [firstborn], Er, did ·what the LORD said was wicked [evil in the LORD’s sight/eyes], so the LORD ·put him to death [killed him].

4.verse: Judah’s daughter-in-law Tamar gave birth to Perez and Zerah, giving Judah five sons in all [Gen. 38].

5.verse: Perez’s sons were Hezron and Hamul.

6.verse: Zerah had five sons: Zimri, Ethan, Heman, Calcol, and ·Darda [or Dara; 1 Kin. 4:31].

7.verse: Carmi’s son was ·Achan [or Achar; “disaster”; Josh. 7:1], ·who caused trouble for [the troubler of] Israel because he ·took [stole] ·things [plunder] that had been ·given to the LORD to be destroyed [set apart/devoted to the LORD; Josh. 7:16–26].

8.verse: Ethan’s son was Azariah.

9.verse: Hezron’s sons were Jerahmeel, Ram, and ·Caleb [Chelubai; v. 18].

10.verse: Ram was Amminadab’s father, and Amminadab was Nahshon’s father. Nahshon was the leader of the ·people [sons] of Judah.

11.verse: Nahshon was the father of ·Salmon [or Salma; Ruth 4:21], who was the father of Boaz.

12.verse: Boaz was the father of Obed, and Obed was the father of Jesse.

13.verse: Jesse’s ·first son [firstborn] was Eliab. His second son was Abinadab, his third was Shimea,

14.verse: his fourth was Nethanel, his fifth was Raddai,

15.verse: his sixth was Ozem, and his seventh son was David.

16.verse: Their sisters were Zeruiah and Abigail. Zeruiah’s three sons were ·Abishai [or Abshai; 2 Sam. 2:18], Joab, and Asahel.

17.verse: Abigail ·was the mother of [gave birth to] Amasa, and his father was Jether, an Ishmaelite.

18.verse: Caleb’s Family - Caleb son of Hezron ·had [fathered] children by his wife Azubah and by Jerioth [possibly two names for the same woman]. Caleb and Azubah’s sons were Jesher, Shobab, and Ardon.

19.verse: When Azubah died, Caleb married Ephrath. They ·had [gave birth to] a son named Hur,

20.verse: who was the father of Uri, who was the father of Bezalel.

21.verse: Later, when Hezron was sixty years old, he married the daughter of Makir, Gilead’s father. Hezron ·had sexual relations with [went in to] Makir’s daughter, and she ·had [gave birth to] a son named Segub.

22.verse: Segub was the father of Jair. Jair ·controlled [held; owned; ruled] twenty-three cities in the ·country [land; territory] of Gilead.

23.verse: (But Geshur and Aram ·captured [took] the Towns of Jair, as well as Kenath and the ·small towns [villages] around it—sixty towns in all.) All these were descendants of Makir, the father of Gilead.

24.verse: After Hezron died ·in Caleb Ephrathah, his wife Abijah [or Caleb had sexual relations with Ephrath, his father Hezron’s wife, and she] ·had [gave birth to] his son, named Ashhur. Ashhur became the father of Tekoa.

25.verse: Jerahmeel’s Family - Hezron’s ·first son [firstborn] was Jerahmeel. Jerahmeel’s sons were Ram, Bunah, Oren, Ozem, and Ahijah. Ram was Jerahmeel’s ·first son [firstborn].

26.verse: Jerahmeel had another wife, named Atarah. She was the mother of Onam.

27.verse: Jerahmeel’s ·first son [firstborn], Ram, had sons. They were Maaz, Jamin, and Eker.

28.verse: Onam’s sons were Shammai and Jada. Shammai’s sons were Nadab and Abishur.

29.verse: Abishur’s wife was named Abihail, and ·their sons were [she gave birth to] Ahban and Molid.

30.verse: Nadab’s sons were Seled and Appaim. Seled died without having children.

31.verse: Appaim’s son was Ishi, who became the father of Sheshan. Sheshan was the father of Ahlai.

32.verse: Jada was Shammai’s brother, and Jada’s sons were Jether and Jonathan. Jether died without having children.

33.verse: Jonathan’s sons were Peleth and Zaza. These were Jerahmeel’s descendants.

34.verse: Sheshan did not have any sons, only daughters. He had a ·servant [slave] from Egypt named Jarha.

35.verse: Sheshan let his daughter marry his ·servant [slave] Jarha, and she ·had [gave birth to] a son named Attai.

36.verse: Attai was the father of Nathan. Nathan was the father of Zabad.

37.verse: Zabad was the father of Ephlal. Ephlal was the father of Obed.

38.verse: Obed was the father of Jehu. Jehu was the father of Azariah.

39.verse: Azariah was the father of Helez. Helez was the father of Eleasah.

40.verse: Eleasah was the father of Sismai. Sismai was the father of Shallum.

41.verse: Shallum was the father of Jekamiah, and Jekamiah was the father of Elishama.

42.verse: Caleb’s Family - Caleb was Jerahmeel’s brother. Caleb’s ·first son [firstborn] was Mesha. Mesha was the father of Ziph, and his son Mareshah was the father of Hebron.

43.verse: Hebron’s sons were Korah, Tappuah, Rekem, and Shema.

44.verse: Shema was the father of Raham, who was the father of Jorkeam. Rekem was the father of Shammai.

45.verse: Shammai was the father of Maon, and Maon was the father of Beth Zur.

46.verse: Caleb’s ·slave woman [concubine; a secondary wife] was named Ephah, and she ·was the mother of [gave birth to] Haran, Moza, and Gazez. Haran was the father of Gazez.

47.verse: Jahdai’s sons were Regem, Jotham, Geshan, Pelet, Ephah, and Shaaph.

48.verse: Caleb had another ·slave woman [concubine; a secondary wife] named Maacah. She ·was the mother of [gave birth to] Sheber, Tirhanah,

49.verse: Shaaph, and Sheva. Shaaph was the father of Madmannah. Sheva was the father of Macbenah and Gibea. Caleb’s daughter was Acsah.

50.verse: These were Caleb’s descendants: Caleb’s son Hur was the ·first son [firstborn] of his mother Ephrathah [called Ephrath in v. 19]. Hur’s sons were Shobal, Salma, and Hareph. Shobal was the father of Kiriath Jearim. Salma was the father of Bethlehem. And Hareph was the father of Beth Gader.

51.verse: These were Caleb’s descendants: Caleb’s son Hur was the ·first son [firstborn] of his mother Ephrathah [called Ephrath in v. 19]. Hur’s sons were Shobal, Salma, and Hareph. Shobal was the father of Kiriath Jearim. Salma was the father of Bethlehem. And Hareph was the father of Beth Gader.

52.verse: Shobal was the father of Kiriath Jearim. Shobal’s descendants were Haroeh, half the Manahathites,

53.verse: and the ·family groups [clans] of Kiriath Jearim: the Ithrites, Puthites, Shumathites, and Mishraites. The Zorathites and the Eshtaolites ·came [descended; went forth] from the Mishraite people.

54.verse: Salma’s descendants were Bethlehem, the Netophathites, Atroth Beth Joab, half the Manahathites, and the Zorites.

55.verse: His descendants included the families who lived at Jabez, who ·wrote and copied important papers [were scribes]. They were called the Tirathites, Shimeathites, and Sucathites and were from the Kenite ·family group [clan] who came from Hammath. He was the father of the ·people living in [house of] Recab.

1.verse: David’s Family - These are David’s sons who were born in Hebron. The first was Amnon [2 Sam. 13], whose mother was Ahinoam from Jezreel. The second son was Daniel, whose mother was Abigail from Carmel.

2.verse: The third son was Absalom, whose mother was Maacah daughter of Talmai, the king of Geshur. The fourth son was Adonijah [1 Kin. 1:5–27], whose mother was Haggith.

3.verse: The fifth son was Shephatiah, whose mother was Abital. The sixth son was Ithream, whose mother was Eglah.

4.verse: These six sons of David were born to him in Hebron, where David ruled for seven and one-half years. David ruled in Jerusalem thirty-three years.

5.verse: These were his children who were born in Jerusalem: ·Shammua [or Shimea; 2 Sam. 5:14], Shobab, Nathan, and Solomon—the four children of David and ·Bathsheba [or Bathshua; 2 Sam. 12:24], Ammiel’s daughter.

6.verse: David’s other nine children were Ibhar, ·Elishua [or Elishama; apparently not the same son as later in the list; 2 Sam. 5:16], ·Eliphelet [or Elpelet, 2 Sam. 5:16]; apparently not the same son as at the end of this list], Nogah, Nepheg, Japhia, Elishama, Eliada, and Eliphelet.

7.verse: David’s other nine children were Ibhar, ·Elishua [or Elishama; apparently not the same son as later in the list; 2 Sam. 5:16], ·Eliphelet [or Elpelet, 2 Sam. 5:16]; apparently not the same son as at the end of this list], Nogah, Nepheg, Japhia, Elishama, Eliada, and Eliphelet.

8.verse: David’s other nine children were Ibhar, ·Elishua [or Elishama; apparently not the same son as later in the list; 2 Sam. 5:16], ·Eliphelet [or Elpelet, 2 Sam. 5:16]; apparently not the same son as at the end of this list], Nogah, Nepheg, Japhia, Elishama, Eliada, and Eliphelet.

9.verse: These were all of David’s sons, except for those born to his ·slave women [concubines; secondary wives]. Tamar was their sister.

10.verse: The Kings of Judah - Solomon’s son was Rehoboam. Rehoboam’s son was Abijah. Abijah’s son was Asa. Asa’s son was Jehoshaphat.

11.verse: Jehoshaphat’s son was ·Jehoram [or Joram; a variant of the same name]. ·Jehoram’s [or Joram’s] son was Ahaziah. Ahaziah’s son was Joash.

12.verse: Joash’s son was Amaziah. Amaziah’s son was Azariah. Azariah’s son was Jotham.

13.verse: Jotham’s son was Ahaz. Ahaz’s son was Hezekiah. Hezekiah’s son was Manasseh.

14.verse: Manasseh’s son was Amon, and Amon’s son was Josiah.

15.verse: These were Josiah’s sons: His ·first son [firstborn] was Johanan, his second was Jehoiakim, his third was Zedekiah, and his fourth was Shallum.

16.verse: Jehoiakim was ·followed [succeeded] by ·Jehoiachin [or Jeconiah], and he was ·followed by [succeeded by his son] Zedekiah.

17.verse: David’s Descendants After the Babylonian Captivity - ·Jehoiachin [or Jeconiah] was taken as a prisoner [2 Chr. 36:10]. His sons were Shealtiel,

18.verse: Malkiram, Pedaiah, Shenazzar, Jekamiah, Hoshama, and Nedabiah.

19.verse: Pedaiah’s sons were Zerubbabel and Shimei. Zerubbabel’s sons were Meshullam and Hananiah, and their sister was Shelomith.

20.verse: Zerubbabel also had five other sons: Hashubah, Ohel, Berekiah, Hasadiah, and Jushab-Hesed.

21.verse: Hananiah’s descendants were Pelatiah and ·Jeshaiah, and the sons of Rephaiah, Arnan, Obadiah, and Shecaniah [or his son Jeshaiah, and Jeshaiah’s son Rephaiah, and Rephaiah’s son Arnan, and Arnan’s son Obadiah, and Obadiah’s son Shecaniah].

22.verse: Shecaniah’s son was Shemaiah. Shemaiah’s sons were Hattush, Igal, Bariah, Neariah, and Shaphat. There were six in all.

23.verse: Neariah had three sons: Elioenai, Hizkiah, and Azrikam.

24.verse: Elioenai had seven sons: Hodaviah, Eliashib, Pelaiah, Akkub, Johanan, Delaiah, and Anani.

1.verse: Other Family Groups of Judah - Judah’s descendants were Perez, Hezron, Carmi, Hur, and Shobal.

2.verse: Reaiah was Shobal’s son. Reaiah was the father of Jahath, and Jahath was the father of Ahumai and Lahad. They were the ·family groups [clans] of the Zorathite people.

3.verse: Hur was the ·oldest son [firstborn] of Caleb and his wife Ephrathah. Hur was the ·leader [father] of Bethlehem. His three sons were Etam, Penuel, and Ezer. Etam’s sons were Jezreel, Ishma, and Idbash. They had a sister named Hazzelelponi. Penuel was the father of Gedor, and Ezer was the father of Hushah.

4.verse: Hur was the ·oldest son [firstborn] of Caleb and his wife Ephrathah. Hur was the ·leader [father] of Bethlehem. His three sons were Etam, Penuel, and Ezer. Etam’s sons were Jezreel, Ishma, and Idbash. They had a sister named Hazzelelponi. Penuel was the father of Gedor, and Ezer was the father of Hushah.

5.verse: Tekoa’s father was Ashhur. Ashhur had two wives named Helah and Naarah.

6.verse: Naarah gave birth to Ahuzzam, Hepher, Temeni, and Haahashtari. These were the descendants of Naarah.

7.verse: Helah’s sons were Zereth, Zohar, Ethnan,

8.verse: and Koz. Koz was the father of Anub, Hazzobebah, and the Aharhel ·family group [clan]. Aharhel was the son of Harum.

9.verse: There was a man named Jabez, who was more ·respected [honorable; honored; known] than his brothers. His mother named him Jabez [sounds like the word for “pain”] because she said, “I was in much pain when I gave birth to him.”

10.verse: Jabez ·prayed [called/cried out] to the God of Israel, “·Please [Oh that/If only you would] ·do good things for me [bless me] and ·give me more land [enlarge/extend/expand my territory/border]. ·Stay [Keep your hand] with me, and ·don’t let anyone hurt me [keep me from harm/trouble]. ·Then […so that] I ·won’t have any [will be free from/not have to endure] pain.” And God ·did what Jabez had asked [granted/answered his request/prayer].

11.verse: Kelub, Shuhah’s brother, was the father of Mehir. Mehir was the father of Eshton.

12.verse: Eshton was the father of Beth Rapha, Paseah, and Tehinnah. Tehinnah was the father of the people from the town of Nahash. These ·people were [are the men/descendants] from Recah.

13.verse: The sons of Kenaz were Othniel and Seraiah. Othniel’s sons were Hathath and Meonothai.

14.verse: Meonothai was the father of Ophrah. Seraiah was the father of Joab. Joab was the ·ancestor of the people from [father/founder of] ·Craftsmen’s Valley [Geharashim], named that because they were ·craftsmen [artisans].

15.verse: Caleb was Jephunneh’s son. Caleb’s sons were Iru, Elah, and Naam. Elah’s son was Kenaz.

16.verse: Jehallelel’s sons were Ziph, Ziphah, Tiria, and Asarel.

17.verse: Ezrah’s sons were Jether, Mered, Epher, and Jalon. Mered married Bithiah, the daughter of the king of Egypt. The children of Mered and Bithiah were Miriam, Shammai, and Ishbah. Ishbah was the father of Eshtemoa. Mered also had a wife from Judah, who gave birth to Jered, Heber, and Jekuthiel. Jered became the father of Gedor. Heber became the father of Soco. And Jekuthiel became the father of Zanoah.

18.verse: Ezrah’s sons were Jether, Mered, Epher, and Jalon. Mered married Bithiah, the daughter of the king of Egypt. The children of Mered and Bithiah were Miriam, Shammai, and Ishbah. Ishbah was the father of Eshtemoa. Mered also had a wife from Judah, who gave birth to Jered, Heber, and Jekuthiel. Jered became the father of Gedor. Heber became the father of Soco. And Jekuthiel became the father of Zanoah.

19.verse: Hodiah’s wife was Naham’s sister. The sons of Hodiah’s wife were Eshtemoa and the father of Keilah. Keilah was from the Garmite people, and Eshtemoa was from the Maacathite people.

20.verse: Shimon’s sons were Amnon, Rinnah, Ben-Hanan, and Tilon. Ishi’s sons were Zoheth and Ben-Zoheth.

21.verse: Shelah was Judah’s son. Shelah’s sons were Er, Laadah, Jokim, the men from Cozeba, Joash, and Saraph. Er was the father of Lecah. Laadah was the father of Mareshah and the ·family groups [clans] of linen workers at Beth Ashbea. Joash and Saraph ·ruled [or married] in Moab ·and Jashubi [or but returned to] Lehem. ·The writings about this family are very old [This is from the ancient records/traditions].

22.verse: Shelah was Judah’s son. Shelah’s sons were Er, Laadah, Jokim, the men from Cozeba, Joash, and Saraph. Er was the father of Lecah. Laadah was the father of Mareshah and the ·family groups [clans] of linen workers at Beth Ashbea. Joash and Saraph ·ruled [or married] in Moab ·and Jashubi [or but returned to] Lehem. ·The writings about this family are very old [This is from the ancient records/traditions].

23.verse: These sons of Shelah were potters. They lived in Netaim and Gederah and worked for the king.

24.verse: Simeon’s Children - Simeon’s sons were Nemuel, Jamin, Jarib, Zerah, and Shaul.

25.verse: Shaul’s son was Shallum. Shallum’s son was Mibsam. Mibsam’s son was Mishma.

26.verse: Mishma’s son was Hammuel. Hammuel’s son was Zaccur. Zaccur’s son was Shimei.

27.verse: Shimei had sixteen sons and six daughters, but his brothers did not have many children, so ·there were not as many people in their family group as there were in [their clan did not grow large/multiply like the sons of] Judah.

28.verse: ·Shimei’s children [They] lived in Beersheba, Moladah, Hazar Shual,

31.verse: Beth Marcaboth, Hazar Susim, Beth Biri, and Shaaraim. They lived in these cities until ·David became king [David’s reign].

32.verse: The five villages near these cities were Etam, Ain, Rimmon, Token, and Ashan.

33.verse: There were also other villages as far away as ·Baalath [Baal]. ·This is where they lived [These were their settlements]. And they ·wrote the history of their family [kept genealogical records].

34.verse: The men in this list were leaders of their ·family groups [clans]: Meshobab, Jamlech, Joshah son of Amaziah, Joel, Jehu son of Joshibiah (Joshibiah was the son of Seraiah, who was the son of Asiel), Elioenai, Jaakobah, Jeshohaiah, Asaiah, Adiel, Jesimiel, Benaiah, and Ziza. (Ziza was the son of Shiphi, who was the son of Allon. Allon was the son of Jedaiah, who was the son of Shimri. And Shimri was the son of Shemaiah.) ·These families [Their father’s houses] grew very large.

35.verse: The men in this list were leaders of their ·family groups [clans]: Meshobab, Jamlech, Joshah son of Amaziah, Joel, Jehu son of Joshibiah (Joshibiah was the son of Seraiah, who was the son of Asiel), Elioenai, Jaakobah, Jeshohaiah, Asaiah, Adiel, Jesimiel, Benaiah, and Ziza. (Ziza was the son of Shiphi, who was the son of Allon. Allon was the son of Jedaiah, who was the son of Shimri. And Shimri was the son of Shemaiah.) ·These families [Their father’s houses] grew very large.

36.verse: The men in this list were leaders of their ·family groups [clans]: Meshobab, Jamlech, Joshah son of Amaziah, Joel, Jehu son of Joshibiah (Joshibiah was the son of Seraiah, who was the son of Asiel), Elioenai, Jaakobah, Jeshohaiah, Asaiah, Adiel, Jesimiel, Benaiah, and Ziza. (Ziza was the son of Shiphi, who was the son of Allon. Allon was the son of Jedaiah, who was the son of Shimri. And Shimri was the son of Shemaiah.) ·These families [Their father’s houses] grew very large.

37.verse: The men in this list were leaders of their ·family groups [clans]: Meshobab, Jamlech, Joshah son of Amaziah, Joel, Jehu son of Joshibiah (Joshibiah was the son of Seraiah, who was the son of Asiel), Elioenai, Jaakobah, Jeshohaiah, Asaiah, Adiel, Jesimiel, Benaiah, and Ziza. (Ziza was the son of Shiphi, who was the son of Allon. Allon was the son of Jedaiah, who was the son of Shimri. And Shimri was the son of Shemaiah.) ·These families [Their father’s houses] grew very large.

38.verse: The men in this list were leaders of their ·family groups [clans]: Meshobab, Jamlech, Joshah son of Amaziah, Joel, Jehu son of Joshibiah (Joshibiah was the son of Seraiah, who was the son of Asiel), Elioenai, Jaakobah, Jeshohaiah, Asaiah, Adiel, Jesimiel, Benaiah, and Ziza. (Ziza was the son of Shiphi, who was the son of Allon. Allon was the son of Jedaiah, who was the son of Shimri. And Shimri was the son of Shemaiah.) ·These families [Their father’s houses] grew very large.

39.verse: They went ·outside [to the entrance/outskirts of] the city of Gedor to the east side of the valley to look for pasture for their flocks.

40.verse: They found ·rich [fertile] and ·good [lush] pasture, and the land was ·open country [broad] and ·peaceful [undisturbed; untroubled] and quiet. Ham’s descendants had lived there ·in the past [formerly].

41.verse: These men ·who were [whose names are] listed came to Gedor while Hezekiah was king of Judah. They ·fought against [attacked] the Hamites, destroying their tents, and also ·against [attacked] the Meunites who lived there, and ·completely destroyed them [or put them under a curse of destruction]. So there are no Meunites there even today. Then these men ·began to live there [lived there in their place], because there was pasture for their flocks.

42.verse: Ishi’s sons, Pelatiah, Neariah, Rephaiah, and Uzziel, led five hundred of the Simeonites and attacked ·the people living in the mountains of Edom [the hill country of Seir; or Mount Seir].

43.verse: They ·killed [destroyed; defeated] the few Amalekites who were still alive. From that time until now these Simeonites have lived in Edom.

1.verse: Reuben’s Children - Reuben was Israel’s [Jacob’s] ·first son [firstborn]. Reuben ·should have received the special privileges of the oldest son [was the firstborn], but he ·had sexual relations with his father’s slave woman [defiled his father’s bed; Gen. 35:22]. So ·those special privileges [that birthright] were given to Joseph’s sons. (Joseph was a son of Israel [Jacob].) In the ·family history Reuben’s name [genealogical record he] is not listed as ·the first son [having the right of the firstborn].

2.verse: Judah became ·stronger than [predominant/prominent over] his brothers, and a leader came from his family [likely referring to David]. But ·Joseph’s family received the privileges that belonged to the oldest son [the birthright belonged to Joseph].

3.verse: Reuben was Israel’s ·first son [firstborn]. Reuben’s sons were Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi.

4.verse: These were the children of Joel: Shemaiah was Joel’s son. Gog was Shemaiah’s son. Shimei was Gog’s son.

5.verse: Micah was Shimei’s son. Reaiah was Micah’s son. Baal was Reaiah’s son.

6.verse: Beerah was Baal’s son. Beerah was a leader of the tribe of Reuben. Tiglath-pileser king of Assyria captured him and took him ·away [into exile/captivity].

7.verse: Joel’s ·brothers [relatives; kinsmen] and all his ·family groups [clans] are listed ·just as they are written in their family histories [according to their genealogical records]: Jeiel was the ·first [leader; chief], then Zechariah,

8.verse: and Bela. (Bela was the son of Azaz. Azaz was the son of Shema, and Shema was the son of Joel.) They lived in the area ·of [that stretches from] Aroer all the way to Nebo and Baal Meon.

9.verse: Bela’s people lived to the east—as far as the edge of the ·desert [wilderness], ·which is beside [that stretches to] the Euphrates River—because they had ·too [so] many cattle ·for [in] the land of Gilead.

10.verse: When Saul was king, Bela’s people fought a war against the Hagrite people ·and defeated them [who fell by their hand]. Then Bela’s people lived in the ·tents [settlements] that had belonged to the Hagrites in all the area east of Gilead.

11.verse: Gad’s Children - The ·people from the tribe [sons] of Gad lived ·near [beside] the Reubenites. The Gadites lived in the area of Bashan all the way to Salecah.

12.verse: Joel was the ·main leader [chief], Shapham was second, and then Janai and Shaphat were leaders in Bashan.

13.verse: The seven ·relatives [brothers] in their ·families [clans] were Michael, Meshullam, Sheba, Jorai, Jacan, Zia, and Eber.

14.verse: They were the descendants of Abihail. Abihail was Huri’s son. Huri was Jaroah’s son. Jaroah was Gilead’s son. Gilead was Michael’s son. Michael was Jeshishai’s son. Jeshishai was Jahdo’s son, and Jahdo was the son of Buz.

15.verse: Ahi was Abdiel’s son, and Abdiel was Guni’s son. Ahi was the leader of their ·family [clans].

16.verse: The Gadites lived in Gilead, Bashan and the small towns around it, and on all the pasturelands in the Plain of Sharon all the way to the borders.

17.verse: All these names were written in the ·family history [genealogical records] of Gad during the time Jotham was king of Judah and Jeroboam was king of Israel.

18.verse: Soldiers Skilled in War - There were forty-four thousand seven hundred sixty ·soldiers [able-bodied/valiant men] from the tribes of Reuben and Gad and ·East [the half-tribe of] Manasseh who carried shields and swords and bows. They were ·skilled in war [trained for battle].

19.verse: They ·started [waged] a war against the Hagrites and the people of Jetur, Naphish, and Nodab.

20.verse: The men from the tribes of Manasseh, Reuben, and Gad ·prayed [cried out] to God during the ·war [battle], asking him to help them. So he helped them because they trusted him. He handed over to them the Hagrites and all those who were with them.

21.verse: They took the animals that belonged to the Hagrites: fifty thousand camels, two hundred fifty thousand sheep, and two thousand donkeys. They also captured one hundred thousand people.

22.verse: Many Hagrites were killed because God helped the people of Reuben, Gad, and Manasseh. Then they ·lived there [occupied their land/territory] until ·Babylon captured them and took them away [the exile/captivity; 2 Chr. 36:17–21].

23.verse: East Manasseh - The many people of ·East [the half-tribe of] Manasseh lived in the area of Bashan all the way to Baal Hermon, Senir, and Mount Hermon.

24.verse: These were the ·family [clan] leaders: Epher, Ishi, Eliel, Azriel, Jeremiah, Hodaviah, and Jahdiel. They were ·all strong, brave [mighty warriors/men of valor], and ·famous men [men of reputation], and ·leaders in their families [head of their clans].

25.verse: But they ·sinned against [were unfaithful to] the God ·that their ancestors had worshiped [of their fathers]. They ·began worshiping [prostituted themselves to] the gods of the people in that land, ·and those were the people God was destroying [whom God had destroyed before them].

26.verse: So the God of Israel ·made Pul king of Assyria want to go to war [stirred up the spirit of Pul king of Assyria]. (Pul was also called Tiglath-pileser [ruled 744–727 BC].) He ·captured [carried into exile] the people of Reuben, Gad, and ·East [the half-tribe of] Manasseh, and he took them away to Halah, Habor, Hara, and near the Gozan River. They have lived there from that time until this day.

1.verse: Levi’s Children - Levi’s sons were Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.

2.verse: Kohath’s sons were Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.

3.verse: Amram’s children were Aaron, Moses, and Miriam. Aaron’s sons were Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar [Ex. 6:23; Lev. 10:1].

4.verse: Eleazar was the father of Phinehas [Num. 25:7, 11; 31:6; Ps. 106:30]. Phinehas was the father of Abishua.

5.verse: Abishua was the father of Bukki. Bukki was the father of Uzzi.

6.verse: Uzzi was the father of Zerahiah. Zerahiah was the father of Meraioth.

7.verse: Meraioth was the father of Amariah. Amariah was the father of Ahitub.

8.verse: Ahitub was the father of Zadok. Zadok was the father of Ahimaaz.

9.verse: Ahimaaz was the father of Azariah. Azariah was the father of Johanan.

10.verse: Johanan was the father of Azariah. (Azariah was a priest in the ·Temple [house] Solomon built in Jerusalem.)

11.verse: Azariah was the father of Amariah. Amariah was the father of Ahitub.

12.verse: Ahitub was the father of Zadok. Zadok was the father of Shallum.

13.verse: Shallum was the father of Hilkiah. Hilkiah was the father of Azariah.

14.verse: Azariah was the father of Seraiah, and Seraiah was the father of Jehozadak.

15.verse: Jehozadak ·was forced to leave his home [went into exile] when the LORD sent Judah and Jerusalem into ·captivity [exile] under Nebu-chadnezzar [2 Kin. 25:1–21; 2 Chr. 36:17–21].

16.verse: Levi’s sons were ·Gershon [or Gershom; v. 1], Kohath, and Merari.

17.verse: The names of ·Gershon’s [or Gershom’s] sons were Libni and Shimei.

18.verse: Kohath’s sons were Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.

19.verse: Merari’s sons were Mahli and Mushi. This is a list of the ·family groups [clans] of Levi, ·listed by the name of the father of each group [by their fathers].

20.verse: ·Gershon’s [or Gershom’s; v. 16] son was Libni. Libni’s son was Jehath. Jehath’s son was Zimmah.

21.verse: Zimmah’s son was Joah. Joah’s son was Iddo. Iddo’s son was Zerah. And Zerah’s son was Jeatherai.

22.verse: Kohath’s ·son [descendant; the list differs from v. 18] was Amminadab. Amminadab’s son was Korah. Korah’s son was Assir.

23.verse: Assir’s son was Elkanah. Elkanah’s son was Ebiasaph. Ebiasaph’s son was Assir.

24.verse: Assir’s son was Tahath. Tahath’s son was Uriel. Uriel’s son was Uzziah, and Uzziah’s son was Shaul.

25.verse: Elkanah’s sons were Amasai and Ahimoth.

26.verse: Ahimoth’s son was Elkanah. Elkanah’s son was Zophai. Zophai’s son was Nahath.

27.verse: Nahath’s son was Eliab. Eliab’s son was Jeroham. Jeroham’s son was Elkanah, and Elkanah’s son was Samuel.

28.verse: Samuel’s sons were Joel, the ·first son [firstborn], and Abijah, the second son [1 Sam. 8:1–3].

29.verse: Merari’s son was Mahli. Mahli’s son was Libni. Libni’s son was Shimei. Shimei’s son was Uzzah.

30.verse: Uzzah’s son was Shimea. Shimea’s son was Haggiah, and Haggiah’s son was Asaiah.

31.verse: The Temple Musicians - David ·chose [appointed; assigned] some people to be in charge of the music in the house of the LORD. They began their work after the ·Ark of the Agreement [Ark] was put there.

32.verse: They ·served by making music [ministered with song] at the ·Holy Tent [Tabernacle] (also called the Meeting Tent), and they served until Solomon built the ·Temple [house] of the LORD in Jerusalem. They ·followed the rules for their work [served according to the regulations].

33.verse: These are ·the musicians [those who served] and their sons: From ·Kohath’s family [the sons of the Kohathites] there was Heman the ·singer [musician]. Heman was Joel’s son. Joel was Samuel’s son.

34.verse: Samuel was Elkanah’s son. Elkanah was Jeroham’s son. Jeroham was Eliel’s son. Eliel was Toah’s son.

35.verse: Toah was Zuph’s son. Zuph was Elkanah’s son. Elkanah was Mahath’s son. Mahath was Amasai’s son.

36.verse: Amasai was Elkanah’s son. Elkanah was Joel’s son. Joel was Azariah’s son. Azariah was Zephaniah’s son.

37.verse: Zephaniah was Tahath’s son. Tahath was Assir’s son. Assir was Ebiasaph’s son. Ebiasaph was Korah’s son.

38.verse: Korah was Izhar’s son. Izhar was Kohath’s son. Kohath was Levi’s son. Levi was Israel’s son.

39.verse: There was Heman’s ·helper [assistant; or kinsman; brother] Asaph, whose group stood by Heman’s right side. Asaph was Berekiah’s son. Berekiah was Shimea’s son.

40.verse: Shimea was Michael’s son. Michael was ·Baaseiah’s son. Baaseiah was Malkijah’s son.

41.verse: Malkijah was Ethni’s son. Ethni was Zerah’s son. Zerah was Adaiah’s son.

42.verse: Adaiah was Ethan’s son. Ethan was Zimmah’s son. Zimmah was Shimei’s son.

43.verse: Shimei was Jahath’s son. Jahath was ·Gershon’s [Gershom’s; v. 16] son, and Gershon was Levi’s son.

44.verse: Merari’s ·family [clan] were the ·helpers [assistants; or kinsmen; brothers;] of Heman and Asaph, and they stood by Heman’s left side. In this group was Ethan son of Kishi. Kishi was Abdi’s son. Abdi was Malluch’s son.

45.verse: Malluch was Hashabiah’s son. Hashabiah was Amaziah’s son. Amaziah was Hilkiah’s son.

46.verse: Hilkiah was Amzi’s son. Amzi was Bani’s son. Bani was Shemer’s son.

47.verse: Shemer was Mahli’s son. Mahli was Mushi’s son. Mushi was Merari’s son, and Merari was Levi’s son.

48.verse: ·The other [Their brothers/kinsmen the] Levites ·served by doing their own special work [were appointed/assigned to other tasks/duties/service] in the ·Holy Tent [Tabernacle], the house of God.

49.verse: Aaron and his descendants offered the sacrifices on the altar of burnt offering [Lev. 1:1–17] and burned the incense on the altar of incense [Ex. 30:1–6]. They offered the sacrifices that ·removed [made atonement for] the Israelites’ sins. They did all the work in the Most Holy Place ·and followed all the laws [according to all] that Moses, God’s servant, had commanded.

50.verse: These were Aaron’s sons: Eleazar was Aaron’s son. Phinehas was Eleazar’s son. Abishua was Phinehas’ son.

51.verse: Bukki was Abishua’s son. Uzzi was Bukki’s son. Zerahiah was Uzzi’s son.

52.verse: Meraioth was Zerahiah’s son. Amariah was Meraioth’s son. Ahitub was Amariah’s son.

53.verse: Zadok was Ahitub’s son, and Ahimaaz was Zadok’s son.

54.verse: Land for the Levites - These are the ·places [settlements; areas] where Aaron’s descendants lived. His descendants from the Kohath ·family group [clan] received the first ·share of the land [or territory by means of sacred lots].

55.verse: They were given the city of Hebron in Judah and the pastures around it,

56.verse: but the fields farther from the city and the villages near Hebron were given to Caleb son of Jephunneh.

57.verse: So the descendants of Aaron were given Hebron, one of the cities of ·safety [refuge]. They also received the towns and pastures of Libnah, Jattir, Eshtemoa,

59.verse: ·Ashan [or Ain; Josh. 21:16], Juttah, and Beth Shemesh.

60.verse: They also received these towns and pastures from the tribe of Benjamin: Gibeon, Geba, Alemeth, and Anathoth. The Kohath ·family groups [clans; Aaron’s descendants] received a total of thirteen towns.

61.verse: The rest of the ·Kohath family group [sons of Kohath] was given ten towns from the ·family groups of West [the half-tribe of] Manasseh. The towns were chosen by ·throwing [sacred] lots.

62.verse: The Gershon ·family group [clan] received thirteen towns from the tribes of Issachar, Asher, Naphtali, and the part of Manasseh living in Bashan.

63.verse: The ·Merari family group [sons/descendants of Merari] received twelve towns from the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and Zebulun. Those towns were chosen by ·throwing [sacred] lots.

64.verse: So the Israelites gave these towns and their pastures to the Levites.

65.verse: The towns from the tribes of Judah, Simeon, and Benjamin, ·which were named [previously mentioned], were chosen by ·throwing [sacred] lots.

66.verse: Some of the Kohath ·family groups [clans] received ·towns and pastures [territory] from the tribe of Ephraim.

67.verse: They received Shechem, one of the cities of ·safety [refuge; someone who accidentally killed another person could receive protection from those seeking revenge; Num. 35:9–34; Josh. 20:1–9], with its pastures in the ·mountains [hill country] of Ephraim. They also received the towns and pastures of Gezer,

70.verse: The rest of the people in the Kohath ·family group [clan] received the towns of Aner and Bileam and their pastures from ·West [the half-tribe of] Manasseh.

71.verse: From ·East [the half-tribe of] Manasseh, the ·Gershon [or Gershom; v. 16] ·family [clan] received the towns and pastures of Golan in Bashan and Ashtaroth.

72.verse: From the tribe of Issachar, the ·Gershon [or Gershom] family received the towns and pastures of Kedesh, Daberath, Ramoth, and Anem.

73.verse: From the tribe of Issachar, the ·Gershon [or Gershom] family received the towns and pastures of Kedesh, Daberath, Ramoth, and Anem.

74.verse: From the tribe of Asher, the ·Gershon [or Gershom] ·family [clan] received the towns and pastures of Mashal, Abdon, Hukok, and Rehob.

75.verse: From the tribe of Asher, the ·Gershon [or Gershom] ·family [clan] received the towns and pastures of Mashal, Abdon, Hukok, and Rehob.

76.verse: From the tribe of Naphtali, the ·Gershon [or Gershom] ·family [clan] received the towns and pastures of Kedesh in Galilee, Hammon, and Kiriathaim.

77.verse: The rest of the Levites, the people from the Merari ·family [clan], received from the tribe of Zebulun the towns and pastures of Jokneam, Kartah, Rimmono, and Tabor.

78.verse: From the tribe of Reuben, the Merari ·family [clan] received the towns and pastures of Bezer in the desert, Jahzah, Kedemoth, and Mephaath. (The tribe of Reuben lived east of the Jordan River, across from Jericho.)

79.verse: From the tribe of Reuben, the Merari ·family [clan] received the towns and pastures of Bezer in the desert, Jahzah, Kedemoth, and Mephaath. (The tribe of Reuben lived east of the Jordan River, across from Jericho.)

80.verse: From the tribe of Gad, ·the Merari family [they] received the towns and pastures of Ramoth in Gilead, Mahanaim, Heshbon, and Jazer.

81.verse: From the tribe of Gad, ·the Merari family [they] received the towns and pastures of Ramoth in Gilead, Mahanaim, Heshbon, and Jazer.

1.verse: Issachar’s Children - Issachar had four sons: Tola, Puah, Jashub, and Shimron.

2.verse: Tola’s sons were Uzzi, Rephaiah, Jeriel, Jahmai, Ibsam, and Samuel, and they were leaders of their ·families [clans]. In the ·family [clan] ·history [genealogy] of Tola’s descendants, twenty-two thousand six hundred men were listed as ·fighting men [warriors; mighty men of valor] during the time ·David was king [of David].

3.verse: Uzzi’s son was Izrahiah. Izrahiah’s sons were Michael, Obadiah, Joel, and Isshiah. All five of them were ·leaders [chiefs].

4.verse: Their ·family [clan] ·history [genealogy] shows they had thirty-six thousand ·men [troops] ready to ·serve in [go to war with] the army, because they had many wives and children.

5.verse: The ·records [genealogy] of the ·family groups [clans] of Issachar show there were eighty-seven thousand ·fighting men [warriors; mighty men of valor].

6.verse: Benjamin’s Children - Benjamin had three sons: Bela, Beker, and Jediael.

7.verse: Bela had five sons: Ezbon, Uzzi, Uzziel, Jerimoth, and Iri, and they were leaders of their ·families [clans]. Their ·family [clan] ·history [genealogy] shows they had twenty-two thousand thirty-four ·fighting men [warriors; mighty men of valor].

8.verse: Beker’s sons were Zemirah, Joash, Eliezer, Elioenai, Omri, Jeremoth, Abijah, Anathoth, and Alemeth. They all were Beker’s sons.

9.verse: Their ·family [clan] ·history [genealogy] listed the ·family [clan] ·leaders [chiefs] and twenty thousand two hundred ·fighting men [warriors; mighty men of valor].

10.verse: Jediael’s son was Bilhan. Bilhan’s sons were Jeush, Benjamin, Ehud, Kenaanah, Zethan, Tarshish, and Ahishahar.

11.verse: All these sons of Jediael were leaders of their ·families [clans]. They had seventeen thousand two hundred ·fighting men [warriors; mighty men of valor] ready to ·serve in [go to war with] the army.

12.verse: The Shuppites and Huppites were descendants of Ir, and the Hushites were descendants of ·Aher [Ahiram; Num. 26:38].

13.verse: Naphtali’s Children - Naphtali’s sons were ·Jahziel [or Jahzeel; Gen. 46:24], Guni, Jezer, and ·Shillem [Shallum; Gen. 46:24, Num. 26:49]. They were Bilhah’s ·grandsons [descendants; Bilhah was Jacob’s concubine].

14.verse: Manasseh’s Children - These are Manasseh’s descendants. Manasseh had an Aramean ·slave woman [concubine; a secondary wife], who ·was the mother of [gave birth to] Asriel and Makir. Makir was Gilead’s father.

15.verse: Makir took a wife from the Huppites and Shuppites. His sister was named Maacah. His second son was named Zelophehad, and he had only daughters.

16.verse: Makir’s wife Maacah ·had [gave birth to] a son whom she named Peresh. Peresh’s brother was named Sheresh. Sheresh’s sons were Ulam and Rakem.

17.verse: Ulam’s son was Bedan. These were the sons of Gilead, who was the son of Makir. Makir was Manasseh’s son.

18.verse: Makir’s sister Hammoleketh gave birth to Ishhod, Abiezer, and Mahlah.

19.verse: The sons of Shemida were Ahian, Shechem, Likhi, and Aniam.

20.verse: Ephraim’s Children - These are the names of Ephraim’s descendants. Ephraim’s son was Shuthelah. Shuthelah’s son was Bered. Bered’s son was Tahath. Tahath’s son was Eleadah. Eleadah’s son was Tahath.

21.verse: Tahath’s son was Zabad. Zabad’s son was Shuthelah. Ezer and Elead went to Gath to steal ·cows and sheep [cattle; livestock; the term “cattle” can refer to various domesticated animals] and were killed by some men who grew up in that city.

22.verse: Their father Ephraim ·cried [mourned] for them many days, and his ·family [relatives; brothers] came to ·comfort [console] him.

23.verse: Then he ·had sexual relations with [slept with; went in to] his wife again. She became pregnant and gave birth to a son whom Ephraim named Beriah [sounds like “trouble”] because of the ·trouble [disaster; tragedy] that had ·happened to his family [come upon his house].

24.verse: Ephraim’s daughter was Sheerah. She built Lower Beth Horon, Upper Beth Horon, and Uzzen Sheerah.

25.verse: Rephah was Ephraim’s son. Resheph was Rephah’s son. Telah was Resheph’s son. Tahan was Telah’s son.

26.verse: Ladan was Tahan’s son. Ammihud was Ladan’s son. Elishama was Ammihud’s son.

27.verse: Nun was Elishama’s son, and Joshua was the son of ·Nun [or Non; Ex. 33:11].

28.verse: Ephraim’s descendants lived in these lands and towns: Bethel and the villages near it, Naaran on the east, Gezer and the villages near it on the west, and Shechem and the villages near it all the way to Ayyah and its villages.

29.verse: Along the borders of Manasseh’s land were the towns of Beth Shan, Taanach, Megiddo, and Dor, and the villages near them. The descendants of Joseph son of Israel [Jacob] lived in these towns.

30.verse: Asher’s Children - Asher’s sons were Imnah, Ishvah, Ishvi, and Beriah. Their sister was Serah.

31.verse: Beriah’s sons were Heber and Malkiel. Malkiel was Birzaith’s father.

32.verse: Heber was the father of Japhlet, Shomer, Hotham, and their sister Shua.

33.verse: Japhlet’s sons were Pasach, Bimhal, and Ashvath. They were Japhlet’s children.

34.verse: Japhlet’s brother was ·Shemer [or Shomer; v. 32]. Shemer’s sons were Rohgah, ·Hubbah [or Jachbah; the text says Jachbah; the marginal reading has Hubbah], and Aram.

35.verse: Shemer’s brother was ·Helem [or Hotham; v. 32]. Helem’s sons were Zophah, Imna, Shelesh, and Amal.

36.verse: Zophah’s sons were Suah, Harnepher, Shual, Beri, Imrah,

37.verse: Bezer, Hod, Shamma, Shilshah, Ithran [perhaps another name for Jether; v. 38], and Beera.

38.verse: Jether’s sons were Jephunneh, Pispah, and Ara.

39.verse: Ulla’s sons were Arah, Hanniel, and Rizia.

40.verse: All these men were descendants of Asher and leaders of their ·families [clans]. They were ·powerful warriors [mighty men of valor] and ·outstanding leaders [chief of princes]. Their ·family history [genealogical record] lists that they had twenty-six thousand soldiers ready to ·serve in [go to war with] the army.

1.verse: The Family History of King Saul - Benjamin was the father of Bela, his ·first son [firstborn]. Ashbel was his second son, Aharah was his third,

2.verse: Nohah was his fourth, and Rapha was his fifth son.

3.verse: Bela’s sons were Addar, Gera, Abihud,

4.verse: Abishua, Naaman, Ahoah,

5.verse: Gera, Shephuphan, and Huram.

6.verse: These were the descendants of Ehud and leaders of their ·families [clans] in Geba. They were ·forced to move [exiled; deported] to Manahath.

7.verse: Ehud’s descendants were Naaman, Ahijah, and ·Gera [or Geba]. ·Gera [or Geba] ·forced them to leave [led them into exile]. He was the father of Uzza and Ahihud.

8.verse: Shaharaim and his wife Hushim had sons named Abitub and Elpaal. In Moab, Shaharaim ·divorced [sent away] his wives Hushim and Baara. Shaharaim and his wife Hodesh had these sons: Jobab, Zibia, Mesha, Malcam, Jeuz, Sakia, and Mirmah. They were leaders of their ·families [clans].

9.verse: Shaharaim and his wife Hushim had sons named Abitub and Elpaal. In Moab, Shaharaim ·divorced [sent away] his wives Hushim and Baara. Shaharaim and his wife Hodesh had these sons: Jobab, Zibia, Mesha, Malcam, Jeuz, Sakia, and Mirmah. They were leaders of their ·families [clans].

10.verse: Shaharaim and his wife Hushim had sons named Abitub and Elpaal. In Moab, Shaharaim ·divorced [sent away] his wives Hushim and Baara. Shaharaim and his wife Hodesh had these sons: Jobab, Zibia, Mesha, Malcam, Jeuz, Sakia, and Mirmah. They were leaders of their ·families [clans].

12.verse: Elpaal’s sons were Eber, Misham, Shemed, Beriah, and Shema. Shemed built the towns of Ono and Lod and the villages around them. Beriah and Shema were leaders of the ·families [clans] living in Aijalon, and they ·forced out [drove out; routed] the people who lived in Gath.

13.verse: Elpaal’s sons were Eber, Misham, Shemed, Beriah, and Shema. Shemed built the towns of Ono and Lod and the villages around them. Beriah and Shema were leaders of the ·families [clans] living in Aijalon, and they ·forced out [drove out; routed] the people who lived in Gath.

14.verse: Beriah’s sons were Ahio, Shashak, Jeremoth,

15.verse: Zebadiah, Arad, Eder,

16.verse: Michael, Ishpah, and Joha.

18.verse: Ishmerai, Izliah, and Jobab.

19.verse: Shimei’s sons were Jakim, Zicri, Zabdi,

20.verse: Elienai, Zillethai, Eliel,

21.verse: Adaiah, Beraiah, and Shimrath.

22.verse: Shashak’s sons were Ishpan, Eber, Eliel,

23.verse: Abdon, Zicri, Hanan,

24.verse: Hananiah, Elam, Anthothijah,

25.verse: Iphdeiah, and Penuel.

26.verse: Jeroham’s sons were Shamsherai, Shehariah, Athaliah,

28.verse: The ·family histories [genealogical records] show that all these men were leaders of their ·families [clans] and lived in Jerusalem.

29.verse: Jeiel lived in the town of Gibeon, where he was the leader. His wife was named Maacah.

30.verse: Jeiel’s ·first son [firstborn] was Abdon. His other sons were Zur, Kish, Baal, Ner, Nadab,

32.verse: and Mikloth. Mikloth was the father of Shimeah. These sons also lived ·near [with; across from] their relatives in Jerusalem.

33.verse: Ner was the father of Kish. Kish was the father of Saul, and Saul was the father of Jonathan, Malki-Shua, Abinadab, and Esh-Baal [Ishbosheth; 2 Sam. 2:8].

35.verse: Micah’s sons were Pithon, Melech, Tarea, and Ahaz.

36.verse: Ahaz was the father of Jehoaddah. Jehoaddah was the father of Alemeth, Azmaveth, and Zimri. Zimri was the father of Moza.

37.verse: Moza was the father of Binea. Raphah was Binea’s son. Eleasah was Raphah’s son, and Azel was Eleasah’s son.

38.verse: Azel had six sons: Azrikam, ·Bokeru [or the firstborn], Ishmael, Sheariah, Obadiah, and Hanan. All these were Azel’s sons.

39.verse: Azel’s brother was Eshek. Eshek’s ·first son [firstborn] was Ulam, his second was Jeush, and Eliphelet was his third.

40.verse: Ulam’s sons were mighty ·warriors [men of valor] and good archers. They had many sons and grandsons—one hundred fifty of them in all. All these men were Benjamin’s descendants.

1.verse: The People in Jerusalem - The names of all the people of Israel were listed in their ·family histories [genealogical records], and those ·family histories [genealogical records] were put in the ·book [scroll] of the kings of Israel. The people of Judah were captured and ·forced to go [exiled] to Babylon [2 Kin. 25:1–21; 2 Chr. 36:17–21], because ·they were not faithful to God [of their unfaithfulness/infidelity].

2.verse: The first people to come back and live in their own lands and towns were some Israelites, priests, Levites, and ·Temple [house] servants.

3.verse: People from the tribes of Judah, Benjamin, Ephraim, and Manasseh lived in Jerusalem. This is a list of those people.

4.verse: There was Uthai son of Ammihud. (Ammihud was Omri’s son. Omri was Imri’s son. Imri was Bani’s son. Bani was a descendant of Perez, and Perez was Judah’s son.)

6.verse: Of the Zerahite people there were Jeuel and other relatives of Zerah. There were six hundred ninety ·of them [or families] in all.

7.verse: From the ·tribe [sons] of Benjamin there was Sallu son of Meshullam. (Meshullam was Hodaviah’s son, and Hodaviah was Hassenuah’s son.)

8.verse: There was also Ibneiah son of Jeroham and Elah son of Uzzi. (Uzzi was Micri’s son.) And there was Meshullam son of Shephatiah. (Shephatiah was Reuel’s son, and Reuel was Ibnijah’s son.)

9.verse: The ·family history [genealogical record] of Benjamin lists nine hundred fifty-six ·people [or families] living in Jerusalem, and all these were leaders of their ·families [clans].

10.verse: Of the priests there were Jedaiah, Jehoiarib, Jakin, and

11.verse: Azariah son of Hilkiah. (Hilkiah was Meshullam’s son. Meshullam was Zadok’s son. Zadok was Meraioth’s son. Meraioth was Ahitub’s son. Ahitub was the officer ·responsible for [in charge of] the ·Temple [house] of God.)

12.verse: Also there was Adaiah son of Jeroham. (Jeroham was Pashhur’s son, and Pashhur was Malkijah’s son.) And there was Maasai son of Adiel. (Adiel was Jahzerah’s son. Jahzerah was Meshullam’s son. Meshullam was Meshillemith’s son, and Meshillemith was Immer’s son.)

13.verse: There were one thousand seven hundred sixty priests. They were leaders of their ·families [clans], and they were ·responsible [capable] for serving in the ·Temple [house] of God.

14.verse: Of the Levites there was Shemaiah son of Hasshub. (Hasshub was Azrikam’s son, and Azrikam was Hashabiah’s son. Hashabiah was ·from the family [a descendant; of the sons of] of Merari.)

15.verse: There were also Bakbakkar, Heresh, Galal, and Mattaniah son of Mica. (Mica was Zicri’s son, and Zicri was Asaph’s son.)

16.verse: There was also Obadiah son of Shemaiah. (Shemaiah was Galal’s son, and Galal was Jeduthun’s son.) And there was Berekiah son of Asa. (Asa was the son of Elkanah, who lived in the ·villages [area] of the Netophathites.)

17.verse: Of the gatekeepers there were Shallum, Akkub, Talmon, Ahiman, and their relatives. Shallum was ·their leader [the chief].

18.verse: These gatekeepers ·from [for] the ·tribe [camp] of Levi ·still stand [or previously stood] next to the King’s Gate on the east side of the city.

19.verse: Shallum was Kore’s son. Kore was Ebiasaph’s son, and Ebiasaph was Korah’s son. Shallum and his relatives from the ·family [clan] of Korah were gatekeepers and were ·responsible for [in charge of] guarding the ·gates of the Temple [threshold of the tent/sanctuary/Tabernacle]. Their ancestors had also been ·responsible for [in charge of] guarding the entrance to the ·Temple [camp; dwelling] of the LORD.

20.verse: In the past Phinehas, Eleazar’s son, was ·in charge of the [the leader of the] gatekeepers, and the LORD was with Phinehas.

21.verse: Zechariah son of Meshelemiah was the gatekeeper at the entrance to the ·Temple [tent of meeting; Tabernacle].

22.verse: In all, two hundred twelve men were chosen ·to guard the gates [as gatekeepers at the thresholds], and their names were written in their ·family histories [genalogical records] in their villages. David and Samuel the ·seer [prophet] chose these men because they were ·dependable [trustworthy].

23.verse: The gatekeepers and their descendants ·had to guard [were in charge of] the gates of the ·Temple [house] of the LORD when it was a tent.

24.verse: There were gatekeepers on all four sides of the ·Temple [house]: east, west, north, and south.

25.verse: The gatekeepers’ relatives who lived in the villages had to come and help them at times. ·Each time they came they helped the gatekeepers for [or They came in every] seven days.

26.verse: Because they were ·dependable [trustworthy], four gatekeepers were made the leaders of all the gatekeepers. They were Levites, and they were ·responsible for [in charge of] the ·rooms [storerooms] and ·treasures [treasuries] in the ·Temple [house] of God.

27.verse: They stayed up all night guarding the ·Temple [house] of God because that was their responsibility, and they opened it every morning.

28.verse: Some of the gatekeepers were ·responsible for [in charge of] the utensils ·used in the Temple services [of service]. They counted these utensils when people took them out and when they brought them back.

29.verse: Other gatekeepers were chosen to take care of the furniture and utensils in the ·Holy Place [sanctuary]. They also took care of the flour, wine, oil, ·incense [frankincense], and spices,

30.verse: but ·some of [sons of] the priests took care of ·mixing [blending] the spices.

31.verse: There was a Levite named Mattithiah who was ·dependable and had the job of [entrusted with] baking the ·bread used for the offerings [flat/unleaven bread; Ex. 25:30; Lev. 24:5–6]. He was the ·first son [firstborn] of Shallum, ·who was from the family of Korah [the Korahite].

32.verse: Some of ·the gatekeepers [their relatives] from the Kohath ·family [clan] had the job of preparing the ·special bread that was put on the table [showbread] every Sabbath day.

33.verse: Some of the Levites were ·musicians in the Temple [singers]. The leaders of these ·families [clans] stayed in the ·rooms of the Temple [chambers]. Since they were on duty day and night, they did not do other ·work in the Temple [service].

34.verse: These are the leaders of the Levite ·families [clans]. Their names were listed in their ·family histories [genealogical records], and they lived in Jerusalem.

35.verse: The Family History of King Saul - Jeiel lived in the town of Gibeon. His wife was named Maacah.

36.verse: Jeiel’s ·first son [firstborn] was Abdon. His other sons were Zur, Kish, Baal, Ner, Nadab,

38.verse: Mikloth was Shimeam’s father. Jeiel’s family lived near their relatives in Jerusalem.

39.verse: Ner was Kish’s father. Kish was Saul’s father. Saul was the father of Jonathan, Malki-Shua, Abinadab, and ·Esh-Baal [or Ishbosheth; 2 Sam. 2:8].

43.verse: Moza was Binea’s father. Rephaiah was Binea’s son. Eleasah was Rephaiah’s son, and Azel was Eleasah’s son.

44.verse: Azel had six sons: Azrikam, ·Bokeru [or the firstborn], Ishmael, Sheariah, Obadiah, and Hanan. They were Azel’s sons.

1.verse: The Death of King Saul - The Philistines ·fought against [attacked] Israel, and the Israelites ran away from them. Many Israelites ·were killed [were slaughtered; fell dead] on Mount Gilboa.

2.verse: The Philistines ·fought hard against [hotly pursued; closed in on] Saul and his sons, killing his sons Jonathan, Abinadab, and Malki-Shua.

3.verse: The fighting was ·heavy [fierce] around Saul, and the archers ·shot him with their arrows [found him] and wounded him.

4.verse: Then Saul said to ·the officer who carried his armor [his armor bearer], “·Pull out [Draw; Take] your sword and ·stab me [run me through]. If you don’t, these Philistines who are not circumcised will come and ·hurt [abuse] me.” But Saul’s ·officer [armor bearer] refused, because he was ·afraid [terrified]. So Saul took his own sword and ·threw himself [fell] on it.

5.verse: When the officer saw that Saul was dead, he ·threw himself [fell] on his own sword and died.

6.verse: So Saul and three of his sons died; all his ·family [house] died together.

7.verse: When the Israelites living in the valley saw that their army had ·run away [fled] and that Saul and his sons were dead, they ·left [abandoned] their towns and ·ran away [fled]. Then the Philistines came and ·settled in [occupied] them.

8.verse: The next day when the Philistines came to strip the dead soldiers, they found Saul and his sons ·dead [fallen] on Mount Gilboa.

9.verse: The Philistines stripped Saul’s body and took his head and his armor. Then they sent messengers through ·all their country [the land of the Philistines] to tell the good news to their idols and to their people.

10.verse: The Philistines put Saul’s armor in the ·temple [house] of their ·idols [gods] and hung his head in the ·temple [house] of Dagon.

11.verse: All the people in Jabesh Gilead heard what the Philistines had done to Saul.

12.verse: So the ·brave [valiant] men of Jabesh went and got the bodies of Saul and his sons and brought them to Jabesh. They buried their bones under the oak tree in Jabesh [evidently a major landmark]. Then the people of Jabesh fasted for seven days.

13.verse: Saul died because he was not faithful to the LORD and ·did not obey [acted unfaithfully against the word of] the LORD. He even went to a medium and asked her for ·advice [counsel]

14.verse: instead of asking the LORD. This is why the LORD put Saul to death and ·gave [turned over] the kingdom to Jesse’s son David.

1.verse: David Becomes King - Then the people of Israel ·came to [gathered before; joined] David at the town of Hebron and said, “Look, we are your own ·family [bone and flesh].

2.verse: In the past, even when Saul was king, you were the one who led Israel ·in battle [out and brought it in]. The LORD your God said to you, ‘You will be the shepherd for my people Israel. You will be their leader.’”

3.verse: So all the elders of Israel came to King David at Hebron. He made an ·agreement [covenant; treaty] with them in Hebron ·in the presence of [before] the LORD. Then they ·poured oil on [anointed] David to make him king over Israel. ·The LORD had promised through Samuel that this would happen [This was according to the word of the LORD through Samuel].

4.verse: David Captures Jerusalem - David and all the Israelites went to the city of Jerusalem. ·At that time Jerusalem was called […that is,] Jebus, and the people living there were named Jebusites.

5.verse: They said to David, “You can’t ·get inside our city [enter here].” But David ·did take the city of Jerusalem with its strong walls [captured the stronghold/fortress of Zion], and it became the City of David.

6.verse: David had said, “The person who ·leads the [or is the first to] ·attack against [kill one of] the Jebusites will become ·the commander over all my army [commander-in-chief].” Joab son of Zeruiah ·led the attack [went up first], so he became ·the commander of the army [chief].

7.verse: Then David made his home in the ·strong, walled city [stronghold; fortress], which is why it ·was named [is called] the City of David.

8.verse: David rebuilt the city, beginning ·where the land was filled in [with the terraces; the Millo] and going to the ·wall that was around the city [surrounding area/walls]. Joab ·repaired [restored; rebuilt] the other parts of the city.

9.verse: David became ·stronger and stronger [greater and greater], and the LORD ·All-Powerful [of Heaven’s Armies; of hosts] was with him.

10.verse: David’s Mighty Warriors - ·This is a list of the leaders [These are the chiefs/heads] over David’s ·warriors [mighty men] who ·helped make David’s kingdom strong [or strongly supported his kingdom]. All the people of Israel also supported David’s kingdom, ·just as the LORD had promised [according to the word of the LORD].

11.verse: This is a ·list [record; account; roll] of David’s ·warriors [mighty men]: Jashobeam was from the Hacmonite people. He was the head of the ·Three [or Thirty; or officers; David’s most elite soldiers; 11:26–47; 2 Sam. 23:8–39]. He used his spear to fight three hundred men at one time, and he killed them all.

12.verse: Next was Eleazar, one of the Three. Eleazar was Dodai’s son from the Ahohite people.

13.verse: Eleazar was with David at Pas Dammim when the Philistines came there to fight. There was a field of barley at that place. The Israelites ·ran away [fled] from the Philistines,

14.verse: but they ·stopped [took a stand; held their ground] in the middle of that field and ·fought for [defended] it and killed the Philistines. The LORD ·gave them [rescued/saved them with] a great victory.

15.verse: Once, three of the Thirty, David’s chief soldiers, came down to him at the ·rock [cliff face] by the cave near Adullam. At the same time the Philistine army had camped in the Valley of Rephaim.

16.verse: At that time David was in a stronghold, and ·some of the Philistines [a Philistine detachment/garrison] were in Bethlehem.

17.verse: David had a ·strong desire [craving; longing] for some water. He said, “Oh, I wish someone would get me water from the well near the city gate of Bethlehem!”

18.verse: So the Three broke through the Philistine ·army [camp; lines] and took water from the well near the city gate in Bethlehem. Then they brought it to David, but he refused to drink it. He poured it out ·before [as an offering to] the LORD,

19.verse: saying, “·May God keep me from drinking [God forbid that I drink] this water! ·It would be like drinking [Should I drink…?] the blood of the men who risked their lives to bring it to me!” So David refused to drink it. These were the ·brave things [kind of things] that the three warriors did.

20.verse: Abishai brother of Joab was the ·captain [leader; chief] of the Three. Abishai fought three hundred soldiers with his spear and killed them. He ·became as famous as [had a name as did] the ·Three [or Thirty; or officers; v. 11]

21.verse: and was more honored than the ·Three [or Thirty]. He became their commander even though he was not ·one of [or equal to] them.

22.verse: Benaiah son of Jehoiada was a brave fighter from Kabzeel who did mighty things. He killed ·two of the best warriors [or the two sons of Ariel] from Moab. He also went down into a pit and killed a lion on a snowy day.

23.verse: Benaiah killed an Egyptian who was ·about seven and one-half feet [five cubits] tall and had a spear ·as large as [like] a weaver’s ·rod [beam]. Benaiah had a ·club [staff], but he ·grabbed [wrenched] the spear from the Egyptian’s hand and killed him with his own spear.

24.verse: ·These [Such] were the things Benaiah son of Jehoiada did. He ·was as famous as [had a name as well as] the Three.

25.verse: He received more honor than the Thirty, but he did not become a member of the Three. David ·made [appointed] him ·leader [captain] of his bodyguards.

26.verse: The Thirty Chief Soldiers - These were also mighty warriors: Asahel brother of Joab; Elhanan son of Dodo from Bethlehem;

27.verse: ·Shammoth [or Shammah; 2 Sam. 23:25] the Harorite; Helez the ·Pelonite [or Paltite; 2 Sam. 23:26];

28.verse: Ira son of Ikkesh from Tekoa; Abiezer the Anathothite;

29.verse: ·Sibbecai [or Mebunnai; 2 Sam. 23:27] the Hushathite; ·Ilai [or Zalmon; 2 Sam. 23:28] the Ahohite;

30.verse: Maharai the Netophathite; Heled son of Baanah the Netophathite;

31.verse: Ithai son of Ribai from Gibeah in Benjamin; Benaiah the Pirathonite;

32.verse: ·Hurai [or Hiddai; 2 Sam. 23:30] from the ·ravines [valleys; or brooks] of Gaash; ·Abiel [or Abi-Albon; 2 Sam. 23:31] the Arbathite;

33.verse: Azmaveth the ·Baharumite [or Barhumite; 2 Sam. 23:31]; Eliahba the Shaalbonite;

34.verse: the sons of ·Hashem [or Jashen; cf. 2 Sam. 23:32] the Gizonite; Jonathan son of ·Shagee [or Shammah; 2 Sam. 23:33] the Hararite;

35.verse: Ahiam son of ·Sacar [or Sharar; 2 Sam. 23:33] the Hararite; ·Eliphal son of Ur [or Eliphelet son of Ahasbai the Maacathite; 2 Sam. 23:34];

36.verse: Hepher the Mekerathite; Ahijah the Pelonite;

37.verse: ·Hezro [or Hezrai; 2 Sam. 23:35] the Carmelite; Naarai son of Ezbai;

38.verse: Joel brother of ·Nathan [or Igal son of Nathan from Zobah, 2 Sam. 23:36]; Mibhar son of Hagri;

39.verse: Zelek the Ammonite; Naharai the Berothite, the ·officer who carried the armor [armor bearer] for Joab son of Zeruiah;

40.verse: Ira the Ithrite; Gareb the Ithrite;

41.verse: Uriah the Hittite; Zabad son of Ahlai;

42.verse: Adina son of Shiza the Reubenite, who was the ·leader [chief] of the Reubenites, and his thirty soldiers;

43.verse: Hanan son of Maacah; Joshaphat the Mithnite;

44.verse: Uzzia the Ashterathite; Shama and Jeiel sons of Hotham the Aroerite;

45.verse: Jediael son of Shimri; Joha, Jediael’s brother, the Tizite;

46.verse: Eliel the Mahavite; Jeribai and Joshaviah, Elnaam’s sons; Ithmah the Moabite;

47.verse: Eliel, Obed, and Jaasiel the Mezobaites.

1.verse: Warriors Join David - These were the men who came to David at Ziklag when David was ·hiding [banished; kept away] from Saul son of Kish. They were among the ·warriors [champions] who helped David in battle.

2.verse: They ·came [were armed/equipped] with bows for weapons and could use either their right or left hands to shoot arrows or to sling rocks. They were Saul’s relatives from the tribe of Benjamin.

3.verse: Ahiezer was their ·leader [chief], and there was Joash. (Ahiezer and Joash were sons of Shemaah, who was from the town of Gibeah.) There were also Jeziel and Pelet, the sons of Azmaveth. There were Beracah and Jehu from the town of Anathoth.

4.verse: And there was Ishmaiah from the town of Gibeon; he was one of the Thirty. In fact, he was the leader of the Thirty. There were Jeremiah, Jahaziel, Johanan, and Jozabad from Gederah.

5.verse: There were Eluzai, Jerimoth, Bealiah, and Shemariah. There was Shephatiah from Haruph.

6.verse: There were Elkanah, Isshiah, Azarel, Joezer, and Jashobeam from the ·family group of Korah [Korahites].

7.verse: And there were Joelah and Zebadiah, the sons of Jeroham, from the town of Gedor.

8.verse: Part of the people of Gad joined David at his stronghold in the ·desert [wilderness]. They were ·brave warriors [mighty men of valor] trained for war and ·skilled [expert] with shields and spears. They ·were as fierce as [had faces of] lions and as ·fast [swift; or nimble] as gazelles over the hills.

9.verse: Ezer was the leader of Gad’s army, and Obadiah was second in command. Eliab was third,

10.verse: Mishmannah was fourth, Jeremiah was fifth,

11.verse: Attai was sixth, Eliel was seventh,

12.verse: Johanan was eighth, Elzabad was ninth,

13.verse: Jeremiah was tenth, and Macbannai was eleventh in command.

14.verse: They were the ·commanders [leaders; captains] of the army from Gad. The least of these leaders ·was in charge of [or was a match for; could take on; was equal to] a hundred soldiers, and the greatest ·was in charge of [or was a match for; could take on; was equal to] a thousand.

15.verse: They crossed the Jordan River and ·chased away [drove out; put to flight] the people living in the ·valleys [lowlands], to the east and to the west. This happened in the first month of the year when the Jordan ·floods the valley [was overflowing its banks].

16.verse: ·Other people from the tribes [Some of the sons] of Benjamin and Judah also came to David at his stronghold.

17.verse: David went out to meet them and said to them, “If you have come peacefully to help me, ·I welcome you. Join me. […I am your friend; or we will make an alliance; my heart will be united with you]. But if you have come to ·turn me over to my enemies [betray me to my adversaries], even though I have ·done nothing wrong [no violence in my hands], the God of our ·ancestors [fathers] will see this and ·punish you [judge/decide].”

18.verse: Then the Spirit ·entered [came upon; clothed] Amasai, the ·leader [chief] of the Thirty, and he said: “We ·belong to you [are yours], David. We are with you, son of Jesse. ·Success, success [Peace and prosperity] to you. ·Success [Peace] to those who help you, because your God helps you.” So David ·welcomed [received] these men and made them ·leaders [captains] of his ·army [fighters; raiders].

19.verse: Some of the men from Manasseh also ·joined [defected/deserted to] David when he went with the Philistines to fight Saul. But David and his men did not really help the Philistines. After ·talking about it [consultation], the Philistine leaders decided to send David away. They said, “If David ·goes [defects; deserts] back to his master Saul, ·we will be killed [it will be our heads].”

20.verse: These are the men from Manasseh who ·joined [defected/deserted to] David when he went to Ziklag: Adnah, Jozabad, Jediael, Michael, Jozabad, Elihu, and Zillethai. Each of them was a ·leader [captain; chief] of a thousand men from Manasseh.

21.verse: All these men of Manasseh were ·brave soldiers [mighty men of valor], and they helped David fight against ·groups of men who went around the country robbing people [raiding bands]. These soldiers became ·commanders [captains] in David’s army.

22.verse: Every day more men ·joined [came to help] David, and his army became ·large [great], like the army of God.

23.verse: Others Join David at Hebron - These are the numbers of the soldiers ·ready [armed] for battle who ·joined [came to] David at Hebron. They came to help turn the kingdom of Saul over to David, ·just as the LORD had said [according to the word of the LORD].

24.verse: There were sixty-eight hundred armed ·men from [descendants/sons of] Judah, carrying shields and spears.

25.verse: There were seventy-one hundred men from Simeon. They were ·warriors [mighty men of valor] ready for war.

26.verse: There were forty-six hundred ·men from [descendants/sons of] Levi.

27.verse: Jehoiada, a leader from Aaron’s family, was in that group. There were thirty-seven hundred with him.

15.verse: Joab son of Zeruiah was commander over the army. Jehoshaphat son of Ahilud was the ·recorder [secretary; royal historian].

16.verse: Zadok son of Ahitub and Abiathar son of Ahimelech were priests. ·Shavsha [or Seriah; 2 Sam. 8:17] was the royal ·secretary [scribe].

17.verse: Benaiah son of Jehoiada was over the Kerethites and Pelethites [foreign mercenaries who served as the king’s bodyguards]. And David’s sons were ·important officers who served [chief officials/assistants] at his side.

1.verse: War with the Ammonites and Arameans - When Nahash king of the Ammonites died, his son became king after him.

2.verse: David said, “Nahash ·was loyal [showed kindness] to me, so I will ·be loyal [show kindness] to his son Hanun.” So David sent messengers to ·comfort [express sympathy to] Hanun about his father’s death. David’s officers went to the land of the Ammonites to ·comfort [express sympathy to] Hanun.

3.verse: But the Ammonite ·leaders [officials; commanders] said to Hanun, “Do you think David wants to honor your father by sending men to ·comfort you [express sympathy]? No! David sent them to ·study [search; explore] the land and ·capture [conquer; overthrow] it and spy it out.”

4.verse: So Hanun ·arrested [seized] David’s officers. He shaved their beards and cut off their clothes at the ·hips [buttocks; both intended to shame them]. Then he sent them away.

5.verse: When the people told David what had happened to ·his officers [the men], he sent messengers to meet them, because they were ·very ashamed [greatly humiliated]. King David said, “Stay in Jericho until your beards have grown back. Then come home.”

6.verse: ·The Ammonites knew that they had insulted [When the Ammonites realized they had become disgusting/a stench to] David. So Hanun and the Ammonites sent ·about seventy-four thousand pounds [one thousand talents] of silver to hire chariots and chariot drivers from ·northwest Mesopotamia [Aram-naharaim], Aram Maacah, and Zobah.

7.verse: The Ammonites hired thirty-two thousand chariots and the king of Maacah and his ·army [people]. So they came and set up camp near the town of Medeba. The Ammonites themselves ·came out of [assembled/mustered from] their towns and got ready for battle.

8.verse: When David heard about this, he sent Joab with the ·whole army [entire army of warriors/mighty men].

9.verse: The Ammonites came out and ·prepared for battle [drew up in battle lines] at the city ·gate [entrance]. The kings who had come to help were out in the ·field [open country] by themselves.

10.verse: Joab saw that there were enemies both in front of him and behind him. So he chose some of the ·best [elite] soldiers of Israel and ·sent them out to fight [deployed/arrayed them against] the ·Arameans [or Ammonites, 2 Sam. 10:10].
