13.verse: Be ·strong [brave; courageous]. We must fight bravely for our people and the cities of our God. The LORD will do what ·he thinks is right [is good in his sight].”

14.verse: Then Joab and the army with him went to attack the Arameans, and the Arameans ·ran away [fled before him].

15.verse: When the Ammonites saw that the Arameans were ·running away [fleeing], they also ·ran away [fled] from Joab’s brother Abishai and ·went back [retreated] to their city. So Joab went back to Jerusalem.

16.verse: When the Arameans saw that Israel had defeated them, they sent messengers to bring other Arameans from ·east of the Euphrates [beyond the] River. Their leader was ·Shophach [or Shobach; 2 Sam. 10:18], the commander of Hadadezer’s army.

17.verse: When David heard about this, he ·gathered [mobilized; mustered] all the Israelites, and they crossed over the Jordan River. He ·prepared [positioned; deployed] them for battle, facing the Arameans. The Arameans fought with him,

18.verse: but they ·ran away [fled] from the Israelites. David killed seven thousand [seven hundred in 2 Sam. 10:18] Aramean chariot drivers and forty thousand Aramean foot soldiers. He also killed ·Shophach [or Shobach, 2 Sam. 10:18], the commander of the Aramean army.

19.verse: When ·those who served [the subjects/vassals of] Hadadezer saw that the Israelites had defeated them, they made peace with David and ·served him [became his subjects]. So the Arameans ·refused [were unwilling] to help the Ammonites again.

1.verse: Joab Destroys the Ammonites - In the ·spring [turning of the year], the time of year when kings normally went out to ·battle [war], Joab led out the army of Israel. But David stayed in Jerusalem. The army of Israel ·destroyed [ravaged; laid waste] the land of Ammon and went to the city of Rabbah and ·attacked it [lay siege to it; tore it down].

2.verse: David took the crown off the head of ·their king [or Milcom; the god of the Ammonites], and had it placed on his own head. That gold crown weighed ·about seventy-five pounds [one talent], and it ·had valuable gems in it [was set with precious stones]. And David took ·many valuable things [a great amount of plunder/spoil] from the city.

3.verse: He also brought out the people of the city and forced them to work [enslaved them] with saws, iron picks, and axes. David did this to all the Ammonite cities. Then David and all his army returned to Jerusalem.

4.verse: Philistine Giants Are Killed - Later, at Gezer [Gob in 2 Sam. 21:18], war broke out with the Philistines. Sibbecai the Hushathite killed ·Sippai [or Saph; 2 Sam. 21:18], who was one of the descendants of the Rephaites. So those Philistines were ·defeated [subdued; subjugated].

5.verse: Later, there was another battle with the Philistines. Elhanan son of Jair killed Lahmi, the brother of Goliath, who was from the town of Gath. His spear was as ·large [thick] as a weaver’s ·rod [beam; 2 Sam. 21:19].

6.verse: At Gath another battle took place. A huge man was there; he had six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot—twenty-four fingers and toes in all. This man also was ·one of the sons of Rapha [or a descendant of the giants].

7.verse: When he ·spoke against [taunted; defied] Israel, Jonathan son of Shimea, David’s brother, killed him.

8.verse: These descendants ·of Rapha [from the giants] from Gath were killed by David and his ·men [warriors].

1.verse: David Counts the Israelites - ·Satan was against [or An adversary opposed] Israel, and he ·caused [incited] David to ·count [take a census of; doing so implied trust in themselves rather than in God] the people of Israel.

2.verse: So David said to Joab and the commanders of the troops, “Go and ·count [take a census of] all the Israelites from Beersheba to Dan [the whole expanse of Israel from south to north]. Then tell me so I will know how many there are.”

3.verse: But Joab said, “May the LORD give the ·nation [or army] a hundred times more people. My ·master [lord] the king, ·all the Israelites are [are they not all…?] your servants. Why do you want to do this, my master? ·You will make Israel guilty of sin [Why should you bring guilt/judgment to Israel?].”

4.verse: But the ·king commanded [king’s word/edict prevailed despite] Joab, so Joab left and went through all Israel. Then he returned to Jerusalem.

5.verse: Joab gave the ·list [number] of the ·people [soldiers; warriors] to David. There were one million one hundred thousand men in all of Israel who could use the sword, and there were four hundred seventy thousand men in Judah who could use the sword.

6.verse: But Joab did not count the tribes of Levi and Benjamin, because he ·didn’t like [was repulsed/disgusted/distressed by] King David’s order.

7.verse: David had done something ·God had said was wrong [that displeased/offended God], so God ·punished [attacked; struck] Israel [taking a census of the army indicated confidence in military strength].

8.verse: Then David said to God, “I have sinned greatly by what I have done! Now, I beg you to ·forgive me, [take away the guilt/iniquity of] your servant, because I have been very foolish.”

9.verse: The LORD said to Gad, who was David’s ·seer [prophet],

10.verse: “Go and tell David, ‘·This is what the LORD says [Thus says the LORD]: I offer you three ·choices [things]. Choose one of them and I will ·do it [inflict it on you].’”

11.verse: So Gad went to David and said to him, “·This is what the LORD says [Thus says the LORD]: ‘·Choose for yourself [Take your choice:]

12.verse: three years of ·hunger [famine]. Or choose three months of ·running from [being swept away by] your enemies as they ·chase [overtake] you with their swords. Or choose three days of ·punishment from [the sword of] the LORD, in which a ·terrible disease [plague; pestilence] will spread through the ·country [land]. The angel of the LORD will go through Israel ·destroying [ravaging] the people.’ Now, David, decide ·which of these things [what answer] I should ·tell [give] the LORD who sent me.”

13.verse: David said to Gad, “I am in ·great trouble [deep distress; a desperate situation]. Let ·the LORD punish me [me fall into the hand of the LORD], because the LORD is very merciful. Don’t let ·my punishment come from [me fall into the hand of] human beings.”

14.verse: So the LORD sent a ·terrible disease [plague; pestilence] on Israel, and seventy thousand people died.

15.verse: God sent an angel to destroy Jerusalem, but when the angel ·started [was about/preparing] to destroy it, the LORD saw it and ·felt very sorry about the terrible things that had happened [relented regarding the disaster/calamity]. So he said to the angel who was destroying, “That is enough! ·Put down your arm [Withhold your hand]!” The angel of the LORD was then standing at the threshing floor of ·Araunah [or Ornan; or Aravna; 2 Sam. 24:16] the Jebusite.

16.verse: David looked up and saw the angel of the LORD ·in the sky [standing between earth and heaven], with his drawn sword in this hand ·pointing toward [extended over] Jerusalem. Then David and the ·elders [leaders] bowed facedown on the ground. They were wearing ·rough cloth [sackcloth; burlap; a sign of grief or repentance].

17.verse: David said to God, “·I am [Am not I…?] the one who sinned and did wrong. I gave the order for the ·people to be counted [census]. ·These people only followed me like sheep. They did nothing wrong. [These sheep—what have they done?] LORD my God, please ·punish [let your hand fall on] me and my ·family [father’s house], but ·stop the terrible disease that is killing [lift the plague from] your people.”

18.verse: Then the angel of the LORD ·told [ordered; commanded] Gad to tell David that he should build an altar to the LORD on the threshing floor of ·Araunah [or Ornan; or Aravna; 2 Sam. 24:16] the Jebusite.

19.verse: So David ·did what Gad told him to do, [went up as Gad had spoken/instructed/commanded] in the name of the LORD.

20.verse: ·Araunah [or Ornan; or Aravna; 2 Sam. 24:16] was ·separating the wheat from the straw [threshing wheat]. When he turned around, he saw the angel. Araunah’s four sons who were with him hid themselves.

21.verse: David came to Araunah, and when Araunah saw him, he left the threshing floor and bowed facedown on the ground before David.

22.verse: David said to him, “·Sell me [Let me have] your threshing floor so I can build an altar to the LORD here. Then the ·terrible disease will stop [plague will be lifted from the people]. ·Sell it to me for the full price [I’ll pay top price; Full silver].”

23.verse: ·Araunah [or Ornan; or Aravna; v. 18] said to David, “Take this threshing floor. My master the king, do ·anything you want [whatever is good in your eyes]. Look, I will also give you oxen for the whole burnt offerings [Lev. 1:1–17], the threshing ·boards [sledges; sleds] for the wood, and wheat for the ·grain [gift; tribute] offering [Lev. 2:1]. I give everything to you.”

24.verse: But King David answered Araunah, “No, I ·will pay [insist on paying] the full price for the land. I won’t take anything that is yours and give it to the LORD. I won’t offer a burnt offering [Lev. 1:1–17] that costs me nothing.”

25.verse: So David paid ·Araunah [or Ornan; or Aravna; v. 18] ·about fifteen pounds [six hundred shekels] of gold for the place.

26.verse: David built an altar to the LORD there [the site of the future Temple; 2 Chr. 3:1] and offered whole burnt offerings [Lev. 1:1–17] and ·fellowship [or peace; well-being] offerings [Lev. 3:1]. David ·prayed to [called on] the LORD, and he answered him by sending down fire from heaven on the altar of burnt offering.

27.verse: Then the LORD commanded the angel to put his sword back into its ·holder [sheath].

28.verse: When David saw that the LORD had answered him on the threshing floor of ·Araunah [or Ornan; or Aravna; v. 18], he offered sacrifices there.

29.verse: The ·Holy Tent [Tabernacle] that Moses made while the Israelites were in the ·desert [wilderness] and the altar of burnt offerings [Lev. 1:1–17] were in Gibeon at the ·place of worship [high place].

30.verse: But David could not go ·to the Holy Tent to speak with [before it to inquire of] God, because he was ·afraid [terrified] of the sword of the angel of the LORD.

1.verse: David said, “The ·Temple [house] of the LORD God and the altar for Israel’s burnt offerings [Lev. 1:1–17] will be here.”

2.verse: David Makes Plans for the Temple - So David ordered all ·foreigners [sojourners; resident aliens] living in Israel to gather together. From that group David ·chose [appointed; assigned] stonecutters to cut stones to be used in building the ·Temple [house] of God.

3.verse: David supplied a large amount of iron to be used for making nails and ·hinges [clamps; braces; fittings] for the gate doors. He also supplied more bronze than could be weighed,

4.verse: and he supplied more cedar logs than could be counted. ·Much of the [Great quantities of] cedar had been brought to David by the people from Sidon and Tyre.

5.verse: David said, “We should build a ·great [exceedingly magnificent] ·Temple [house] for the LORD, which will be famous everywhere for its ·greatness and beauty [splendor; gloriousness]. But my son Solomon is young and ·inexperienced [tender], so I will make preparations for it.” So David got many of the materials ready before he died.

6.verse: Then David called for his son Solomon and ·told [commanded; charged] him to build the ·Temple [house] for the LORD, the God of Israel.

7.verse: David said to him, “My son, I ·wanted [intended; planned; had my heart set] to build a ·temple [house] ·for worshiping [to the name of] the LORD my God.

8.verse: But the LORD spoke his word to me, ‘David, you have ·killed many people [shed much blood]. You have fought ·many [great] wars. You cannot build a ·temple [house] ·for worship to me [to my name], because you have ·killed many people [shed so much blood on the earth in my sight; he completed the conquest of Canaan].

9.verse: But, you will have a son, a man of ·peace [rest]. I will give him rest from all his enemies around him. His name will be Solomon [a name derived from shalom, “peace”], and I will give Israel peace and quiet ·while he is king [in his days].

10.verse: Solomon will build a ·temple [house] for ·worship to me [my name]. He will be my son, and I will be his father [2 Sam. 7:14; Ps. 2:7]. I will ·make his kingdom strong; someone from his family will rule [establish/secure his throne over] Israel forever.’”

11.verse: David said, “Now, my son, may the LORD be with you and give you success. May you build a ·temple [house] for the LORD your God, as he ·said [announced; promised] you would.

12.verse: When he makes you the king of Israel, may the LORD give you ·wisdom [discretion] and understanding so you will be able to ·obey [keep; observe] the ·teachings [law; instructions] of the LORD your God.

13.verse: Be careful to obey the ·rules [statutes; ordinances; requirements] and laws the LORD ·gave [commanded] Moses for Israel. If you obey them, you will ·have success [prosper]. Be strong and brave. Don’t be afraid or ·discouraged [dismayed].

14.verse: “Solomon, I have ·worked hard getting many of the materials [taken great pains to provide] for building the ·Temple [house] of the LORD. I have supplied ·about seven and one-half million pounds [one hundred thousand talents] of gold, ·about seventy-five million pounds [one million talents] of silver, so much bronze and iron it cannot be weighed, and wood and stone. You may add to them.

15.verse: You have many workmen—stonecutters, ·bricklayers [stonemasons], carpenters, and ·people skilled [craftsmen; artisans] in every kind of work.

16.verse: They are skilled in working with gold, silver, bronze, and iron. You have more craftsmen than can be counted. ·Now begin the [Set to] work, and may the LORD be with you.”

17.verse: Then David ·ordered [commanded] all the leaders of Israel to help his son Solomon.

18.verse: David said to them, “The LORD your God is with you. He has given you ·rest from our enemies [peace on every side; Deut. 12:2]. He has handed over to me the people living around us. The LORD and his people ·are in control of [have subdued] this land.

19.verse: Now ·give yourselves completely to obeying [devote your heart/mind and soul to seeking] the LORD your God. Build the ·holy place [sanctuary] of the LORD God; build the ·Temple [house] ·for worship to the LORD [to honor the LORD’s name]. Then bring the Ark of the ·Agreement [Testimony; Treaty; Covenant] with the LORD and the holy ·items [vessels; articles] that belong to God into the ·Temple [house].”

1.verse: The Levites - After David ·had lived long [was full of years] and was old, he made his son Solomon the new king of Israel.

2.verse: David gathered all the leaders of Israel, along with the priests and Levites.

3.verse: He counted the Levites who were thirty years old and older, and they totaled thirty-eight thousand.

4.verse: David said, “Of these, twenty-four thousand Levites will ·direct [oversee; supervise] the work of the ·Temple [house] of the LORD, six thousand Levites will be ·officers [officials] and judges,

5.verse: four thousand Levites will be gatekeepers, and four thousand Levites will praise the LORD with musical instruments I made for ·giving praise [worship].”

6.verse: David separated the Levites into three groups that were led by Levi’s three sons: Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.

7.verse: The People of Gershon - From the people of Gershon [6:1], there were Ladan and Shimei.

8.verse: Ladan had three sons. His first son was Jehiel, and his other sons were Zetham and Joel.

9.verse: Shimei’s sons were Shelomoth, Haziel, and Haran. These three sons were leaders of Ladan’s ·families [clans].

10.verse: Shimei had four sons: Jahath, Ziza, Jeush, and Beriah.

11.verse: Jahath was the ·first son [eldest; chief; family leader], and Ziza was the second son. But Jeush and Beriah did not have many children, so they were counted as if they were one family, with one ·assignment [responsibility].

12.verse: The People of Kohath - Kohath had four sons: Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.

13.verse: Amram’s sons were Aaron and Moses. Aaron and his descendants were ·chosen to be special [set apart] forever. They were chosen to ·prepare [dedicate; sanctify] the holy things, to ·offer sacrifices [burn incense] before the LORD, and to ·serve [minister to] him. They were to ·give [pronounce] blessings in his name forever.

14.verse: Moses was the man of God, and his sons were counted as part of the tribe of Levi.

15.verse: Moses’ sons were Gershom [Judg. 18:30] and Eliezer.

16.verse: Gershom’s ·first [oldest; chief] son was Shubael.

17.verse: Eliezer’s ·first [oldest; chief] son was Rehabiah. Eliezer had no other sons, but Rehabiah had many sons.

18.verse: Izhar’s ·first [oldest; chief] son was Shelomith.

19.verse: Hebron’s ·first [oldest; chief] son was Jeriah, his second was Amariah, his third was Jahaziel, and his fourth was Jekameam.

20.verse: Uzziel’s ·first [oldest; chief] son was Micah and his second was Isshiah.

21.verse: The People of Merari - Merari’s sons were Mahli and Mushi. Mahli’s sons were Eleazar and Kish.

22.verse: Eleazar died without sons; he had only daughters. Eleazar’s daughters married their cousins, the sons of Kish.

23.verse: Mushi’s three sons were Mahli, Eder, and Jerimoth.

24.verse: The Levites’ Work - These were Levi’s descendants listed by ·their families [clans]. They were the leaders of families. Each person who was twenty years old or older was ·listed [counted]. They served in the LORD’s ·Temple [house].

25.verse: David had said, “The LORD, the God of Israel, has given ·rest [peace] to his people. He ·has come to live [dwells] in Jerusalem forever.

26.verse: So the Levites don’t need to carry the ·Holy Tent [Tabernacle] or any of the ·things [articles; objects] used in its services anymore.”

27.verse: David’s ·last [final] instructions were to count the Levites who were twenty years old and older.

28.verse: The Levites had the ·job [duty; office] of ·helping [assisting] Aaron’s descendants in the service of the ·Temple [house] of the LORD. They cared for the ·Temple [house] ·courtyard [courts] and side rooms, and they ·made all the holy things pure [ceremonially purified all holy/sacred things]. Their job was to serve in the ·Temple [house] of God.

29.verse: They were ·responsible for [in charge of] putting the ·holy bread [showbread] on the table, for the choice flour in the grain offerings, for the ·bread made without yeast [unleaven bread/wafers], for the ·baking and mixing [or the round cakes], and for the measuring of quantity or size.

30.verse: The Levites also stood every morning and gave thanks and praise to the LORD. They also did this every evening.

31.verse: The Levites offered all the burnt offerings [Lev. 1:1–17] to the LORD on the ·special days of rest [sabbaths], at the New Moon festivals [Num. 10:10; 29:6; 1 Sam. 20:5; 2 Kin. 4:23; Ezra 3:5; Ps. 81:3; Is. 1:13; Amos 8:5], and at all appointed feasts. They served before the LORD ·every day [continually]. They were to follow the rules for how many Levites should serve each time.

32.verse: So the Levites ·took care [were in charge] of the ·Meeting Tent [Tabernacle] and the ·Holy Place [sanctuary]. And they helped their relatives, Aaron’s descendants, with the services at the ·Temple [house] of the LORD.

1.verse: The Groups of the Priests - These were the ·groups [divisions; orders] of Aaron’s sons: Aaron’s sons were Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.

2.verse: But Nadab and Abihu died before their father did [Lev. 10:1–2], and they had no sons. So Eleazar and Ithamar served as the priests.

3.verse: David, with the help of Zadok, a descendant of Eleazar, and Ahimelech, ·a descendant of Ithamar, separated their [Aaron’s] ·family groups [descendants] into two different groups according to their ·various duties [assigned responsibilities/offices].

4.verse: There were more ·leaders [chiefs] from Eleazar’s ·family [descendants] than from Ithamar’s—sixteen ·leaders [heads of their clans] from Eleazar’s ·family [descendants] and eight ·leaders [heads of their clans] from Ithamar’s ·family [descendants].

5.verse: Men were ·chosen [divided; allocated; organized] ·impartially [or similarly] from Eleazar’s and Ithamar’s ·families [descendants] by throwing lots. Some men ·from each family were chosen to be in charge [were officials] of the ·Holy Place [sanctuary], and some were ·chosen to serve as priests [officials of God].

6.verse: Shemaiah son of Nethanel, ·from the tribe [son] of Levi, was the ·secretary [recorder; scribe]. He recorded the names of those descendants in ·front [the presence] of King David, the ·officers [officials; leaders], Zadok the priest, Ahimelech son of Abiathar, and the leaders of the ·families [clans] of the priests and Levites. The work was divided by lots among the ·families [clans] of Eleazar and Ithamar.

7.verse: The first ·one chosen was [lot fell to] Jehoiarib. The second was Jedaiah.

8.verse: The third was Harim. The fourth was Seorim.

9.verse: The fifth was Malkijah. The sixth was Mijamin.

10.verse: The seventh was Hakkoz. The eighth was Abijah.

11.verse: The ninth was Jeshua. The tenth was Shecaniah.

12.verse: The eleventh was Eliashib. The twelfth was Jakim.

13.verse: The thirteenth was Huppah. The fourteenth was Jeshebeab.

14.verse: The fifteenth was Bilgah. The sixteenth was Immer.

15.verse: The seventeenth was Hezir. The eighteenth was Happizzez.

16.verse: The nineteenth was Pethahiah. The twentieth was Jehezkel.

17.verse: The twenty-first was Jakin. The twenty-second was Gamul.

18.verse: The twenty-third was Delaiah. The twenty-fourth was Maaziah.

19.verse: These were ·the groups chosen to serve [or their appointed duties; the order of their serving] in the ·Temple [house] of the LORD. They obeyed the ·rules [procedures; regulations] given them by Aaron, just as the LORD, the God of Israel, had commanded him.

20.verse: The Other Levites - These are the names of the rest of Levi’s descendants: Shubael was a descendant of Amram, and Jehdeiah was a descendant of Shubael.

21.verse: Isshiah was the ·first [firstborn; chief] son of Rehabiah.

22.verse: From the Izhar ·family group [clan], there was Shelomoth, and Jahath was a descendant of Shelomoth.

23.verse: Hebron’s ·first son was [descendants included] Jeriah, Amariah was his second, Jahaziel was his third, and Jekameam was his fourth.

24.verse: Uzziel’s ·son was [descendants included] Micah. Micah’s son was Shamir.

25.verse: Micah’s brother was Isshiah, and Isshiah’s ·son was [descendants included] Zechariah.

26.verse: Merari’s descendants were Mahli and Mushi. Merari’s son was Jaaziah.

27.verse: Jaaziah ·son [descendant] of Merari had ·sons [descendants] named Shoham, Zaccur, and Ibri.

28.verse: Mahli’s ·son [descendant] was Eleazar, but Eleazar did not have any sons.

30.verse: Mushi’s ·sons were [descendants included] Mahli, Eder, and Jerimoth. These are the Levites, listed by their ·families [clans].

31.verse: They ·were chosen for special jobs by throwing [cast] lots in front of King David, Zadok, Ahimelech, the leaders of the ·families [clans] of the priests, and the Levites. They did this just as their relatives, Aaron’s descendants, had done. The families of the oldest brother and the youngest brother were treated the same.

1.verse: The Music Groups - David and the ·commanders [officers] of the army chose some of the sons of Asaph, Heman, and Jeduthun to ·preach [proclaim; prophesy] and play harps, lyres, and cymbals. Here is a list of the men who ·served in this way [performed/were assigned these services]:

2.verse: Asaph’s sons who served were Zaccur, Joseph, Nethaniah, and Asarelah. King David ·chose [directed] Asaph to ·preach [proclaim; prophesy], and Asaph directed his sons.

3.verse: Jeduthun’s sons who served were Gedaliah, ·Zeri [or Izri; v. 11], Jeshaiah, Shimei [name not included in most manuscripts], Hashabiah, and Mattithiah. There were six of them, and Jeduthun directed them. He ·preached [proclaimed; prophesied] and used a harp to give thanks and praise to the LORD.

9.verse: First, the lot fell to Joseph, from the ·family [clan] of Asaph [the number twelve needs to be understood here, as in the following verses, to make the total come to the stated 288]. Second, twelve men were chosen from Gedaliah, his sons and ·relatives [kinsmen; brothers].

1.verse: The Gatekeepers - These are the ·groups [divisions; orders] of the gatekeepers. From the ·family [clan] of Korah, there was Meshelemiah son of Kore, who was from Asaph’s ·family [descendants].

2.verse: Meshelemiah had sons. Zechariah was his ·first son [firstborn], Jediael was second, Zebadiah was third, Jathniel was fourth,

3.verse: Elam was fifth, Jehohanan was sixth, and Eliehoenai was seventh.

4.verse: Obed-Edom had sons. Shemaiah was his ·first son [firstborn], Jehozabad was second, Joah was third, Sacar was fourth, Nethanel was fifth,

5.verse: Ammiel was sixth, Issachar was seventh, and Peullethai was eighth. God indeed blessed Obed-Edom.

6.verse: Obed-Edom’s son Shemaiah also had sons. They ·were leaders in [ruled over] their father’s ·family [house] because they were ·capable men [highly respected; mighty men of valor].

7.verse: Shemaiah’s sons were Othni, Rephael, Obed and Elzabad, whose ·brothers [relatives] Elihu and Semakiah were ·skilled workers [or valiant men; or also respected].

8.verse: All these were Obed-Edom’s descendants. They and their sons and ·relatives [brothers; grandsons] were capable men and ·strong [well-qualified] workers. Obed-Edom had sixty-two ·descendants [relatives] in all.

9.verse: Meshelemiah had sons and ·relatives [brothers] who were ·skilled workers [capable/respected men]. In all, there were eighteen.

10.verse: From the Merari ·family [clan], Hosah had sons. Shimri, although not the oldest son, was chosen by his father to be in charge.

11.verse: Hilkiah was his second son, Tabaliah was third, and Zechariah was fourth. In all, Hosah had thirteen sons and ·relatives [brothers].

12.verse: These were the leaders of the ·groups [divisions; orders] of gatekeepers, and they served in the ·Temple [house] of the LORD, as did their ·relatives [brothers].

13.verse: By throwing lots, each ·family [clan] chose a gate to guard. ·Young [Small] and ·old [great] threw lots.

14.verse: ·Meshelemiah [or Shelemiah; v. 2] was chosen by lot to guard the East Gate. Then lots were ·thrown [cast] for Meshelemiah’s son Zechariah. He was a ·wise counselor [prudent advisor] and was chosen for the North Gate.

15.verse: Obed-Edom was ·chosen for [allotted] the South Gate, and Obed-Edom’s sons were ·chosen to guard [allotted] the storehouse.

16.verse: Shuppim and Hosah were chosen for the West Gate and the Shalleketh Gate on the ·upper [ascending] road [to the Temple]. ·Guards stood side by side with guards [or Guard duty was evenly divided; A guard alongside a guard].

17.verse: Six Levites stood guard every day at the East Gate; four stood guard every day at the North Gate; four stood guard every day at the South Gate; and two at a time guarded the storehouse.

18.verse: There were two guards at the ·western court [colonnade; Parbar; the gateway leading up to the Temple] and four guards on the road.

19.verse: These were the ·groups [divisions; orders] of the gatekeepers from the ·families [clans; sons] of Korah and Merari.

20.verse: Other Leaders - ·Other [Their fellow/brother] Levites were ·responsible for guarding [in charge of] the treasuries of the ·Temple [house] of God and for the ·places where the holy items were kept [treasuries of dedicated/consecrated gifts].

21.verse: ·Ladan [or Libni] was Gershon’s son and the ancestor of several ·family groups [clans]. ·Jehiel [or Jehieli; 23:8] was a ·leader [chief] of one of the ·family groups [clans].

22.verse: His sons were Zetham and Joel his brother, and they were ·responsible for [in charge of] the treasuries of the ·Temple [house] of the LORD.

23.verse: Other leaders were chosen from the ·family groups [clans] of Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.

24.verse: Shubael, the descendant of Gershom, who was Moses’ son, was the ·leader [chief] ·responsible for [in charge of] the treasuries.

25.verse: These were Shubael’s relatives from Eliezer: Eliezer’s son Rehabiah, Rehabiah’s son Jeshaiah, Jeshaiah’s son Joram, Joram’s son Zicri, and Zicri’s son Shelomith.

26.verse: Shelomith and his relatives were ·responsible for [in charge of] ·everything that had been collected for the Temple [the treasuries of dedicated/consecrated gifts collected] by King David, by the heads of ·families [clans], by the commanders of a thousand men and of a hundred men, and by other army ·commanders [officers].

27.verse: They also ·gave [dedicated] some of the ·things they had [plunder; spoil] taken in wars to be used in repairing the ·Temple [house] of the LORD.

28.verse: Shelomith and his relatives took care of all the ·holy items [dedicated/consecrated gifts]. Some had been given by Samuel the ·seer [prophet], Saul son of Kish, Abner son of Ner, and Joab son of Zeruiah.

29.verse: Kenaniah was from the Izhar ·family [clan]. He and his sons worked outside the ·Temple [house] as officers and judges in Israel.

30.verse: Hashabiah was from the Hebron ·family [clan]. He and his relatives were ·responsible for [in charge of] the LORD’s work and ·the king’s business [served the king] in Israel west of the Jordan River. There were seventeen hundred ·skilled [capable; respected] men in Hashabiah’s group.

31.verse: The ·history [genealogy] of the Hebron ·family [clan] shows that Jeriah was their ·leader [chief]. In David’s fortieth year ·as king [of reign], the ·records [genealogies] were searched, and some ·capable [skilled; respected] men of the Hebron ·family [clan] were found living at Jazer in Gilead.

32.verse: Jeriah had twenty-seven hundred relatives who were ·capable [skilled; respected] men and leaders of families. King David ·gave them the responsibility of directing [put them in charge of] the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and ·East [the half-tribe of] Manasseh in God’s work and the king’s ·business [service].

1.verse: Army Divisions - This is the list of the Israelites who served the king in the army. Each division was on duty one month each year. There were leaders of ·families [clans], commanders of a thousand men, commanders of a hundred men, and other officers. Each division had twenty-four thousand men.

2.verse: Jashobeam son of Zabdiel was in charge of the first division for the first month. There were twenty-four thousand men in his division.

3.verse: Jashobeam, one of the descendants of Perez, was ·leader [chief; commander] of all the army officers for the first month.

4.verse: Dodai, from the Ahohites, was in charge of the division for the second month. Mikloth was a ·leader [chief; commander] in the division. There were twenty-four thousand men in Dodai’s division.

5.verse: The third commander, for the third month, was Benaiah son of Jehoiada the priest. There were twenty-four thousand men in his division.

6.verse: He was the Benaiah who was one of the Thirty [11:11]. Benaiah was a ·brave [mighty] warrior who led those men. Benaiah’s son Ammizabad was in charge of Benaiah’s division.

7.verse: The fourth commander, for the fourth month, was Asahel, the brother of Joab. Later, Asahel’s son Zebadiah ·took his place as commander [succeeded him]. There were twenty-four thousand men in his division.

8.verse: The fifth commander, for the fifth month, was Shamhuth, from Izrah’s ·family [clan]. There were twenty-four thousand men in his division.

9.verse: The sixth commander, for the sixth month, was Ira son of Ikkesh from the town of Tekoa. There were twenty-four thousand men in his division.

10.verse: The seventh commander, for the seventh month, was Helez. He was from the Pelonites and a descendant of Ephraim. There were twenty-four thousand men in his division.

11.verse: The eighth commander, for the eighth month, was Sibbecai. He was from Hushah and was from Zerah’s ·family [clan]. There were twenty-four thousand men in his division.

12.verse: The ninth commander, for the ninth month, was Abiezer. He was from Anathoth in Benjamin. There were twenty-four thousand men in his division.

13.verse: The tenth commander, for the tenth month, was Maharai. He was from Netophah and was from Zerah’s ·family [clan]. There were twenty-four thousand men in his division.

14.verse: The eleventh commander, for the eleventh month, was Benaiah. He was from Pirathon in Ephraim. There were twenty-four thousand men in his division.

15.verse: The twelfth commander, for the twelfth month, was Heldai. He was from Netophah and was from Othniel’s ·family [clan]. There were twenty-four thousand men in his division.

16.verse: Leaders of the Tribes - These were ·the leaders [in charge] of the tribes of Israel. Eliezer son of Zicri was over the tribe of Reuben. Shephatiah son of Maacah was over the tribe of Simeon.

17.verse: Hashabiah son of Kemuel was over the tribe of Levi. Zadok was over the people of Aaron.

18.verse: Elihu, one of David’s brothers, was over the tribe of Judah. Omri son of Michael was over the tribe of Issachar.

19.verse: Ishmaiah son of Obadiah was over the tribe of Zebulun. Jerimoth son of Azriel was over the tribe of Naphtali.

20.verse: Hoshea son of Azaziah was over the tribe of Ephraim. Joel son of Pedaiah was over ·West [the half-tribe of] Manasseh.

21.verse: Iddo son of Zechariah was over ·East Manasseh [the half-tribe of Manasseh in Gilead]. Jaasiel son of Abner was over the tribe of Benjamin.

22.verse: Azarel son of Jeroham was over the tribe of Dan. These were the ·leaders [chiefs; commanders] of the tribes of Israel.

23.verse: The LORD had promised to make the Israelites as ·many [numerous] as the stars ·in the sky [of heaven; Gen. 22:17; 26:4; Ex. 32:13]. So David did not count those younger than twenty years old.

24.verse: Joab son of Zeruiah began ·to count [the census of] the people, but he did not finish. ·God became angry with [Wrath came upon] Israel for counting the people, so the number of the people was not put in the ·history book about [chronicles/annals of] King David.

25.verse: The King’s Directors - Azmaveth son of Adiel was in charge of the royal ·storehouses [treasuries]. Jonathan son of Uzziah was in charge of the ·storehouses [treasuries] in the country, towns, villages, and ·towers [fortresses].

26.verse: Ezri son of Kelub was in charge of the field workers who ·farmed [tilled] the land.

27.verse: Shimei, from the town of Ramah, was in charge of the vineyards. Zabdi, from Shapham, was in charge of storing the wine that came from the vineyards.

28.verse: Baal-Hanan, from Geder, was in charge of the olive trees and sycamore trees in the ·western hills [Shephelah]. Joash was in charge of storing the olive oil.

29.verse: Shitrai, from Sharon, was in charge of the herds that ·fed [grazed] in the Plain of Sharon. Shaphat son of Adlai was in charge of the ·herds [cattle] in the valleys.

30.verse: Obil, an Ishmaelite, was in charge of the camels. Jehdeiah, from Meronoth, was in charge of the donkeys.

31.verse: Jaziz, from the Hagrites, was in charge of the flocks. All these men were the ·officers who took care [officials/overseers in charge] of King David’s property.

32.verse: Jonathan was David’s uncle, and he ·advised [counseled] David. Jonathan was a ·wise man [man of understanding/insight] and a ·teacher of the law [scribe]. Jehiel son of Hacmoni ·took care of [taught; tutored] the king’s sons.

33.verse: Ahithophel ·advised [counseled] the king. Hushai, from the Arkite people, was the king’s ·friend [confidant].

34.verse: Jehoiada and Abiathar later took Ahithophel’s place in ·advising [counseling] the king. Jehoiada was Benaiah’s son. Joab was the commander of the king’s army.

1.verse: David’s Plans for the Temple - David ·commanded [summoned] all the ·leaders [officials] of Israel to come to Jerusalem. There were the ·leaders [officials; commanders; chiefs] of the tribes, ·commanders [officers] of the army divisions serving the king, commanders of a thousand men and of a hundred men, ·leaders [officials; overseers] who took care of the property and animals that belonged to the king and his sons, ·men over the palace [palace officials], the ·powerful [mighty] men, and all the ·brave [valiant] warriors.

2.verse: King David stood up and said, “Listen to me, my ·relatives [brothers] and my people. I ·wanted [intended; planned; had my heart set] to build a place to keep the Ark of the ·Agreement [Testimony; Treaty; Covenant] with the LORD. I wanted it to be God’s footstool. So I made ·plans [preparations] to build ·a temple [it].

3.verse: But God said to me, ‘You must not build a ·temple [house] for ·worshiping me [my name/Name], because you are a ·soldier [man of war] and have ·killed many people [shed blood; he completed the conquest of Canaan].’

4.verse: “·But [Yet; Nevertheless] the LORD, the God of Israel, chose me from my whole ·family [clan; father’s house] to be king of Israel forever. He chose the tribe of Judah to ·lead [rule], and from the ·people [house] of Judah, he chose my father’s ·family [clan; house]. From ·that family [my father’s sons] God was pleased to make me king ·of [over all] Israel.

5.verse: The LORD has given me many sons, and from those sons he has chosen Solomon to ·be the new king [sit on the throne] of Israel. Israel is the LORD’s kingdom.

6.verse: The LORD said to me, ‘Your son Solomon will build my ·Temple [house] and ·its courtyards [my courts]. I have chosen Solomon to be my son, and I will be his father.

7.verse: He is obeying my laws and commands now. If he continues ·to obey them [resolutely; unswervingly], I will ·make his kingdom strong [establish/secure his kingdom] forever.’”

8.verse: David said, “Now, in ·front [the sight] of all Israel, the assembly of the LORD, and in the hearing of God, I tell you these things: Be careful to ·obey [observe; follow] all the commands of the LORD your God. Then you will ·keep [possess] this good land and ·pass it on [leave it as an inheritance] to your ·descendants [children] forever.

9.verse: “And you, my son Solomon, ·accept [acknowledge; know] the God of your father. Serve him ·completely and willingly [with your whole heart and a willing mind/spirit], because the LORD ·knows what is in everyone’s mind [searches every heart]. He understands ·everything you think [every desire/motive and thought]. If you ·go to him for help [seek him], ·you will get an answer [you will find him; or he will let you find him]. But if you ·turn away from [abandon; forsake] him, he will ·leave [reject] you forever.

10.verse: Solomon, ·you must understand this [see now]. The LORD has chosen you to build ·the Temple [a house] as his ·holy place [sanctuary]. Be strong and ·finish the job [do it; go to work].”

11.verse: Then David gave his son Solomon the plans for ·building the Temple [the porch/portico]. They included its buildings, its storerooms, its upper rooms, its inside rooms, and the ·place where the people’s sins were removed [room for atonement/the mercy seat].

12.verse: David gave him plans for everything he had in mind: the courtyards around the LORD’s ·Temple [house] and all the rooms around it, the ·Temple treasuries [storehouses of God’s house], and the ·treasuries [storehouse] of the ·holy items used in the Temple [dedicated/consecrated things/gifts].

13.verse: David gave Solomon directions for the ·groups [divisions; orders] of the priests and Levites, and for all the work of serving in the ·Temple [house] of the LORD, and about the ·items [utensils] to be used for service in the ·Temple [house] of the LORD

14.verse: that were made of gold or silver. David told Solomon ·how much [the weight of] gold or silver to use to make each thing.

15.verse: David told him ·how much [the weight of] gold to use for each gold lampstand and its lamps and ·how much [the weight of] silver to use for each silver lampstand and its lamps according to how the lampstands were to be used .

16.verse: David told ·how much [the weight of] gold to use for each table that held the ·holy [show] bread and ·how much [the weight of] silver to use for the silver tables.

17.verse: He told ·how much [the weight of] pure gold to use to make the forks, ·bowls [basins], and pitchers and ·how much [the weight of] gold to use to make each gold ·dish [bowl]. He told ·how much [the weight of] silver to use to make each silver ·dish [bowl]

18.verse: and ·how much [the weight of] pure gold to use for the altar of incense. He also gave Solomon the plans for the ·chariot [or seat] of the ·golden creatures [cherubim] that spread their wings over the Ark of the ·Agreement [Testimony; Treaty; Covenant] with the LORD.

19.verse: David said, “All these plans were written with the LORD ·guiding [directing] me. He ·helped me understand [made clear to me; gave me insight into/understanding of] everything in the plans.”

20.verse: David also said to his son Solomon, “Be strong and brave, and do the work. Don’t be afraid or discouraged, because the LORD God, my God, is with you. He will not fail you or ·leave [abandon; forsake] you until all the work for the service of the ·Temple [house] of the LORD is finished.

21.verse: The ·groups [divisions; orders] of the priests and Levites are ready for all the ·work on [service of] the ·Temple [house] of God. Every skilled worker is ready to help you with all the work. The ·leaders [officials] and all the ·people [nation] will ·obey every command you give [be at your command].”

1.verse: Gifts for Building the Temple - King David said to ·all the Israelites who were gathered [the entire assembly], “God chose my son Solomon, who is young and ·hasn’t yet learned what he needs to know [inexperienced], ·but [and] the ·work is important [task is great/huge]. This ·palace [temple] is not for ·people [mortals]; it is for the LORD God.

2.verse: I have ·done my best [made every effort; according to all my strength] to prepare for building the ·Temple [house] of my God. I have given gold for the things made of gold and silver for the things made of silver. I have given bronze for the things made of bronze and iron for the things made of iron. I have given wood for the things made of wood and onyx for the settings. I have given turquoise gems of many different colors, ·valuable [precious] stones, and ·white marble [alabaster]. I have given all these things in ·abundance [great quantities].

3.verse: I have already given this for the ·Temple [house], but because of my ·devotion to [commitment to; delight in] the ·Temple [house] of my God, I am also giving my own treasures of gold and silver.

4.verse: I am giving ·about two hundred twenty thousand pounds [three thousand talents] of gold from Ophir and ·about five hundred twenty thousand pounds [seven thousand talents] of ·pure [refined] silver. They will be used to ·cover [overlay] the walls of the buildings

5.verse: and for all the gold and silver work to be done by the craftsmen. Now, who is ·ready [willing] to ·give himself [consecrate/devote yourself] to the service of the LORD today [by also making an offering]?”

6.verse: The ·family [clan] leaders and the ·leaders [chiefs; heads] of the tribes of Israel, the commanders of a thousand men and of a hundred men, and the ·leaders [officials; overseers] ·responsible for [in charge of] the king’s work gave willingly.

7.verse: They donated ·about three hundred eighty thousand pounds [five thousand talents] of gold, ·about seven hundred fifty thousand pounds [ten thousand darics] of silver, ·about one million three hundred fifty thousand pounds [eighteen thousand talents] of bronze, and ·about seven million five hundred thousand pounds [one hundred thousand talents] of iron to the ·Temple [house] of God.

8.verse: People who had ·valuable gems [precious stones] gave them to the treasury of the ·Temple [house] of the LORD, under the care of Jehiel, from the Gershon ·family [clan].

9.verse: The leaders gave ·willingly and completely [freely and wholeheartedly] to the LORD. The people rejoiced to see their leaders give so gladly, and King David was also ·very happy [filled with joy].

10.verse: David’s Prayer - David ·praised [blessed] the LORD in ·front [the presence] of all the ·people who were gathered [assembly]. He said: “We ·praise [bless] you, LORD, God of our father Israel, forever and ever.

11.verse: LORD, ·you are great and powerful [yours is the greatness and power]. You have glory, victory, and ·honor [majesty; splendor]. Everything in heaven and on earth belongs to you. ·The kingdom [Sovereignty; Dominion] belongs to you, LORD; you are ·the ruler [head; exalted] over everything.

12.verse: ·Riches [Wealth] and honor come from you. You rule everything. ·You have the [In your hand is] power and ·strength [might] to make ·anyone [everyone] great and strong.

13.verse: Now, our God, we thank you and praise your glorious name.

14.verse: “·These things did not really come from me and my people. [But who am I and who are my people that we have this much to give?] Everything comes from you; we have given you back what ·you [your hand] gave us.

15.verse: We are like ·foreigners [aliens; sojourners] and ·strangers [transients; nomads], as our ·ancestors [fathers] were. Our ·time [days] on earth is like a shadow. There is no ·hope [or security].

16.verse: LORD our God, we have gathered all this abundance to build your ·Temple [house] for ·worship to you [your holy name/Name]. But everything has come from ·you [your hand]; everything belongs to you.

17.verse: I know, my God, that you ·test [examine; search] people’s hearts. You ·are happy when people do what is right [delight/rejoice in integrity/uprightness]. I ·was happy to [willingly; freely] give all these things, and I gave with ·an honest heart [pure motives]. Your people gathered here ·are happy to [willingly] give to you, and I rejoice to see their giving.

18.verse: LORD, you are the God of our ·ancestors [fathers], the God of Abraham, Isaac, and ·Jacob [Israel]. ·Make your people want to serve you always [Keep these motives always in their heart], and ·make them want to obey you [direct their heart toward you].

19.verse: Give my son Solomon a ·desire to serve you [perfect heart; undivided mind; whole heart]. Help him always obey your commands, laws, and rules. Help him build ·the Temple [this temple/palace] for which I have ·prepared [provided].”

20.verse: Then David said to all the ·people who were gathered [assembly], “·Praise [Bless] the LORD your God.” So they all ·praised [blessed] the LORD, the God of their ·ancestors [fathers], and they bowed to the ground ·to give honor to [and prostrated themselves before] the LORD and the king.

21.verse: Solomon Becomes King - The next day the people sacrificed to the LORD. They offered burnt offerings [Lev. 1:1–17] to him of a thousand bulls, a thousand ·male sheep [rams], and a thousand male lambs. They also brought ·drink offerings [libations]. Many sacrifices were made for all the people of Israel.

22.verse: That day the people ·ate and drank [feasted] with much joy, ·and the LORD was with them [before the LORD]. And they ·made [designated; acknowledged] David’s son Solomon king for the second time. They ·poured olive oil on Solomon to appoint [anointed] him king ·in the presence of [before] the LORD. And they ·poured oil on Zadok to appoint him [anointed Zadok] as priest.

23.verse: Then Solomon sat on the LORD’s throne as king and took his father David’s place. Solomon ·was very successful [prospered], and all the people of Israel obeyed him.

24.verse: All the ·leaders [officials; chiefs] and ·soldiers [mighty warriors] and King David’s sons ·accepted Solomon as king and promised to obey him [pledged their allegiance to King Solomon].

25.verse: The LORD ·made Solomon great before [exalted Solomon in the sight of] all the Israelites and gave him greater royal ·splendor [majesty] than any king before him in Israel.

26.verse: David’s Death - David son of Jesse was king over all Israel.

27.verse: He had ·ruled [reigned] over Israel forty years—seven years in Hebron and thirty-three years in Jerusalem.

28.verse: David died when he was old. He had lived a good, long life ·and had received many [full of] riches and honors. His son Solomon ·became king after him [reigned in his place].

29.verse: ·Everything David did as king [The acts/events of King David], from ·beginning to end [first to last], is ·recorded [written] in the ·records [chronicles; annals] of Samuel the ·seer [prophet], the ·records [chronicles; annals] of Nathan the prophet, and the ·records [chronicles; annals] of Gad the ·seer [prophet].

30.verse: Those writings tell what David did ·as king of Israel [during his reign]. They tell about his power and what happened to him and to Israel and to all the kingdoms ·around them [of the earth/land].
